the group announced it was reviving slavery as an institution."<ref name="Theology of Rape">{{cite news|last1=Callimachi|first1=Rukmini|title=ISIS Enshrines a Theology of Rape|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/14/world/middleeast/isis-enshrines-a-theology-of-rape.html?_r=0|accessdate=13 August 2015|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=13 August 2015}}</ref>
==Forced exile== === Flight into Sinjar Mountains and PKK's support === {{see also|Sinjar massacre#Refugee crisis in the Sinjar Mountains}} The ISIL offensive in the Sinjar area of northern Iraq, 3–4 August, caused 30,000–50,000 Yazidis to flee into the [[Sinjar Mountains]] (Jabal Sinjar) fearing they would be killed by ISIL. They had been threatened with death if they refused conversion to Islam. A UN representative said that "a humanitarian tragedy is unfolding in Sinjar".<ref>{{cite news|last1=Salih|first1=Mohammed|last2=van Wilgenburg|first2=Wladimir|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2014/08/iraqi-yazidis-if-move-they-will-kill-us-20148513656188206.html|title=Iraqi Yazidis: 'If we move they will kill us'|date=5 August 2014|publisher=Aljazeera|accessdate=5 August 2014}}</ref>
On 3 and 4 August 14 or more Yazidi children and some elderly or people with disabilities died of hunger, dehydratation, and heat on [[Sinjar Mountains]].<ref name="OHCHR">[http://www.ohchr.org/Documents/Countries/IQ/UNAMI_OHCHR_POC_Report_FINAL_6July_10September2014.pdf Report on the Protection of Civilians in Armed Conflict in Iraq: 6 July – 10 September 2014]. UN Assistance Mission for Iraq (UNAMI) and the Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights (OHCHR). Retrieved 4 April 2015.</ref> By 6 August, according to reports from survivors, 200 Yazidi children while fleeing to Jabal Sinjar had died from thirst, starvation, heat and dehydratation.<ref name="OHCHR"/>
Fifty thousand Yazidis, besieged by ISIL on Mount Sinjar, were able to escape after Kurdish [[People's Protection Units]] and [[Kurdistan Workers' Party|PKK]] broke ISIL siege on the mountains. Majority of them were rescued by Kurdish [[Kurdistan Workers' Party|PKK]] and [[YPG]] fighters.<ref>{{cite news|title=PKK 'terrorists' crucial to fight against Isis|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/4a6e5b90-2460-11e4-be8e-00144feabdc0.html#axzz3zpMUPhOa|accessdate=11 February 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=They're saving Yazidis yet ignored by the US—why?|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2014/08/18/saving-yazidis-yet-ignored-by-the-usiraqcommentary.html|accessdate=11 February 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=PKK saved us when peshmergas ran away: Yazidis|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/world/the-times/pkk-saved-us-when-peshmergas-ran-away-yazidis/news-story/a4cf854079d899f7b7877b6e06b0b2b9|accessdate=11 February 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Smugglers and Kurdish militants help Iraq's Yazidis flee to Turkey|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-iraq-security-turkey-yazidis-idUSKBN0GQ1MX20140826|accessdate=11 February 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Yazidi Refugees Recount Desperate Struggle To Flee Islamist Militants In Iraq|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/08/12/yazidi-refugees-turkey_n_5671365.html#comments|accessdate=11 February 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=A U.S.-designated terrorist group is saving Yazidis and battling the Islamic State|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/worldviews/wp/2014/08/11/a-u-s-designated-terrorist-group-is-saving-yazidis-and-battling-the-islamic-state/|accessdate=11 February 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Kurds unite to fight militants, rescue 30,000 Yazidi civilians|url=http://www.middleeasteye.net/news/kurds-unite-oust-militants-bid-rescue-yazidi-civilians-881764545|accessdate=11 February 2016}}</ref><ref name=kk>{{cite news|title=The Drama of Sinjar: Escaping the Islamic State in Iraq|url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/pkk-assistance-for-yazidis-escaping-the-jihadists-of-the-islamic-state-a-986648.html|accessdate=11 February 2016}}</ref> Multinational rescue operation involved dropping of supplies on the mountains and evacuation of some refugees by helicopters. During the rescue operation, on 12 August, an overloaded Iraqi Air Force helicopter crashed on Mount Sinjar, killing Iraqi Air Force Major General Majid Ahmed Saadi (the pilot) and injuring 20 people.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2723443/Australian-photographer-board-overloaded-Iraqi-helicopter-crashed-killed-pilot-injured-20-evacuees-carrying-aid-Yazidi-refugees.html|title=Australian photographer on board crashed overloaded Iraqi helicopter|work=Mail Online|accessdate=15 March 2015|location=London|date=12 August 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theamericanconservative.com/dreher/general-majid-who-gave-his-life-for-others|title=General Majid, Who Gave His Life For Others|work=The American Conservative|accessdate=6 June 2015}}</ref>
On 8 August, PKK was providing humanitarian aid and camps to more than 3,000 Yazidi refugees.<ref name=kk/>
By 20 October, 2,000 Yazidis, mainly volunteer fighters, who had remained behind to protect the villages, but also civilians (700 families who had not yet escaped), were reported as still in the Sinjar area, and were forced by ISIL to abandon the last villages in their control, Dhoula and Bork, and retreat to the Sinjar Mountains.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/middle_east/islamic-state-seizes-two-yazidi-villages-as-it-advances-on-mount-sinjar/2014/10/20/63cd2a22-9292-4c42-9ff5-41d430ec2819_story.html|title=Islamic State seizes two Yazidi villages as it advances on Mount Sinjar|work=Washington Post|date=20 October 2014|accessdate=15 March 2015|first=Loveday|last=Morris}}</ref>
===Forced conversion=== In an article by ''[[The Washington Post]]'', it is stated that there is an estimated 7,000 Yazidis who had been forced to convert to "the Islamic State group's harsh interpretation of Islam".<ref>{{cite news|title=UN: Assault on Yazidis may be genocide attempt|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/middle_east/un-assault-on-yazidis-may-be-genocide-attempt/2014/10/21/533b136c-597b-11e4-9d6c-756a229d8b18_story.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141022095357/http://www.washingtonpost.com/world/middle_east/un-assault-on-yazidis-may-be-genocide-attempt/2014/10/21/533b136c-597b-11e4-9d6c-756a229d8b18_story.html|archivedate=22 October 2014|accessdate=24 October 2014|agency=The Washington Post|date=21 October 2014|deadurl=yes}}</ref> Yazidi boys were taken to Raqqa, Syria to be trained to fight for ISIL, with some being forced to fight as U.S.-led forces closed in on the group.<ref name="INDboy">{{cite news|title=Yazidi teenager captured by Isis says they were planning 'big, big attack' on Europe|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/isis-tactics-terror-training-iraq-syria-yazidi-teenager-reveals-a7828116.html|accessdate=19 July 2017|work=[[The Independent]]|date=6 July 2017}}</ref><ref>[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/syria-yazidis-isis-islam-conversion-afrin-persecution-kurdish-a8310696.html?amp ] ''The Independent''</ref>
===Return of Yazidi population=== [[File:Yazidi Town Gripped With Challenges Long After IS Removal.webm|thumb|The Yazidi residents of Snune in northern Iraq who returned home faced many challenges]] Following ISIL's retreat from Iraqi and Kurdish forces in the region during late-2017 campaigns, both governments laid claim to the area. The Yazidi population, with only about 15% returning to Sinjar during the period, was caught in the political crossfire. Yazidi's returned to an abandoned town of crumbling buildings, leftover IEDs and the remains of those killed during the massacre.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Jalabi|first1=Raya|title=Yazidis caught in 'political football' between Baghdad, Iraqi Kurds|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-iraq-yazidis/yazidis-caught-in-political-football-between-baghdad-iraqi-kurds-idUSKBN1E40FZ|accessdate=22 December 2017|work=[[Reuters]]|date=10 December 2017}}</ref>
In November 2017, a mass grave of about 70 people was uncovered<ref>{{cite news|title=Yazidi mass grave found in Iraq's Sinjar|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/afp/article-5107265/Yazidi-mass-grave-Iraqs-Sinjar.html|accessdate=22 December 2017|work=Mail Online|date=22 November 2017}}</ref> and a month later in December, another mass grave was discovered holding about 90 victims.<ref>{{cite news|title=Two Yazidi Mass Graves Reportedly Uncovered in Iraq|url=https://www.albawaba.com/news/two-yazidi-mass-graves-reportedly-uncovered-iraq-1061884|accessdate=22 December 2017|work=[[Al Bawaba]]|date=16 December 2017}}</ref>
==Classification as genocide== The persecution of the Yazidi people has been viewed as qualifying as [[genocide]] by groups such as the [[Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights]] in a March 2015 report. The organization cited the numerous atrocities such as [[forced religious conversion]] and [[sexual slavery]] as being parts of an overall malicious campaign.<ref name=BBCRussian/><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2015/03/19/isis-genocide-yazidis_n_6900224.html | work=Huffington Post | title=UN: ISIS May Have Committed Genocide Against Yazidis | date=19 March 2015}}</ref>
On 14 March 2016, the [[United States House of Representatives]] voted unanimously 393-0 that violent actions performed against Yazidis, Christians, [[Shia]] and other groups by ISIL were acts of genocide. Days later on 17 March 2016, [[United States Secretary of State]] [[John Kerry]] declared that the violence initiated by ISIL against the Yazidis and others amounted to genocide.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Labott|first1=Elise|title=U.S. to declare genocide in Iraq and Syria|url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/03/17/politics/us-iraq-syria-genocide/index.html|accessdate=17 March 2016|agency=[[CNN]]|date=17 March 2016}}</ref>
Multiple individual human rights activists such as [[Nazand Begikhani]] and Dr. [[Widad Akrawi]] have also advocated for this view.<ref name="widad.org"/><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.cnn.com/2014/10/30/opinion/isis-yazidi-women-genocide/ | work=CNN | title=Quick Links}}</ref> The term itself first arose in 1944 as the creation of a [[Polish-Jewish]] lawyer named [[Raphael Lemkin]], who himself defined the term as reflecting "a coordinated plan of different actions aiming at the destruction of essential foundations of the life of national groups, with the aim of annihilating the groups themselves."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ushmm.org/confront-genocide/defining-genocide|accessdate=11 August 2015|title=What Is Genocide?|publisher=[[United States Holocaust Memorial Museum]]}}</ref>
==Releases of Yazidi captives== In January 2015, about 200 Yazidis were released by ISIL. Kurdish military officials believed they were released because they were a burden. On 8 April 2015, 216 Yazidis, with the majority being children and elderly, were released by ISIL after being held captive for about 8 months. Their release occurred following an offensive by U.S.-led air assaults and pressure from Iraqi ground forces who were [[Second Battle of Tikrit (March–April 2015)|pushing northward and in the process of retaking Tikrit]]. According to General Hiwa Abdullah, a peshmerga commander in Kirkuk, those released were in poor health with signs of abuse and neglect visible.<ref name=GMrelease>{{cite news|last1=Yacoub|first1=Sameer N.|title=Islamic State releases over 200 Iraqi Yazidis after 8 months as captives|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/islamic-state-releases-over-200-iraqi-yazidis-after-8-months-as-captives/article23844498/|accessdate=9 April 2015|agency=''[[The Globe and Mail]]''|date=8 April 2015|location=Toronto}}</ref>
In March 2016, [[Iraqi people|Iraqi]] security forces managed to free a group of Yazidi women held hostage by [[ISIL]] in a special operation behind ISILs lines in [[Mosul]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-iraq-yazidis-idUSKCN0WI2J3|title=Iraqi forces free group of Yazidi women from Islamic State: ministry|author=Reuters Editorial|date=16 March 2016|work=Reuters}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.alaraby.co.uk/english/news/2016/3/16/iraq-forces-free-yazidi-women-held-by-is|title=Iraqi forces free Yazidi women held by IS|author=The New Arab|work=alaraby}}</ref>
In March 2016, the militant group [[Kurdistan Workers' Party]] managed to free 51 Yazidis held hostages by ISIL in an operation called 'Operation Vengeance for Martyrs of Shilo'<ref>http://anfenglish.com/kurdistan/hpg-and-ybs-yjs-free-51-ezidis-from-isis</ref> Three Kurdistan Workers' Party guerrillas died during the operation.
In April 2016, the Kurdistan Workers' Party with the [[Sinjar Resistance Units]] managed to free another 53 Yazidis held hostages by ISIL.<ref>{{cite news|title=53 more Êzîdîs freed from ISIS|url=http://anfenglish.com/kurdistan/53-more-ezidis-freed-from-isis|accessdate=2 April 2016}}</ref>
==International responses== [[File:Jielbeaumadier manif kurdes ei 1 paris 2014.jpeg|thumb|upright=1.2|Demonstration in [[Paris]] against persecution of Kurds and Yazidis, the sign reading "ISIL is preparing a genocide against Yazidi Kurds".]]
=== Western military intervention=== {{see also|American-led intervention in Iraq (2014–present)}} On 7 August 2014, U.S. President [[Barack Obama]] ordered targeted airstrikes on IS militants and emergency air relief for the Yazidis. Airstrikes began on 8 August. (See [[American-led intervention in Iraq (2014–present)#Obama authorizes airstrikes]].)
On 8 August 2014, the US asserted that the systematic destruction of the Yazidi people by the Islamic State was genocide.<ref>{{cite news|last=Noack|first=Rick|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/worldviews/wp/2014/08/08/when-obama-talks-about-iraq-his-use-of-the-word-genocide-is-vital|title=When Obama talks about Iraq, his use of the word 'genocide' is vital|work=The Washington Post|date=8 August 2014|accessdate=18 August 2014}}</ref>
President Barack Obama had authorized the attacks to protect Yazidis but also Americans and Iraqi minorities. President Obama gave an assurance that no troops would be deployed for combat. Along with the airstrikes of 9 August, the US [[airdrop]]ped 3,800 gallons of water and 16,128 [[MRE]]s. Following these actions, the [[United Kingdom]] and [[France]] stated that they also would begin airdrops.<ref name=CNNaug9>{{cite news|last1=J. Carter|first1=Chelsea|last2=Tawfeeq|first2=Mohammed|last3=Starr|first3=Barbara|title=Officials: U.S. airstrikes pound ISIS militants firing at Iraq's Yazidis|url=http://www.cnn.com/2014/08/09/world/meast/iraq-crisis|accessdate=6 June 2015|agency=CNN|date=9 August 2014}}</ref>
On 10 August 2014, at approximately 2:15 a.m. ET, the US carried out five additional airstrikes on armed vehicles and a mortar position, enabling 20,000–30,000 Yazidi Iraqis to flee into Syria and later be rescued by Kurdish forces. The Kurdish forces then provided shelter for the Yazidis in [[Dohuk]].<ref name=CNNaug10>{{cite news|title=Thousands of Yazidis rescued, Iraqi official says|url=http://www.cnn.com/2014/08/10/world/meast/iraq-crisis/|accessdate=6 June 2015|agency=CNN|date=10 August 2014}}</ref><ref name=GUARDIANaug10>{{cite news|last1=Siddique|first1=Haroon|title=20,000 Iraqis besieged by Isis escape from mountain after US air strikes|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/10/iraq-yazidi-isis-jihadists-islamic-state-kurds|accessdate=6 June 2015|work=The Guardian|date=10 August 2014}}</ref>
On 13 August 2014, fewer than 20 [[United States Special Forces]] troops stationed in Irbil along with British [[Special Air Service]] troops visited the area near Mount Sinjar to gather intelligence and plan the evacuation of approximately 30,000 Yazidis still trapped on Mount Sinjar. One hundred and twenty-nine additional US military personnel were deployed to Irbil to assess and provide a report to President Obama.<ref name=GUARDaug13>{{cite news|last1=Chulov|first1=Martin|last2=Borger|first2=Julian|last3=Norton-Taylor|first3=Richard|last4=Roberts|first4=Dan|title=US troops land on Iraq's Mt Sinjar to plan for Yazidi evacuation|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/13/us-ground-troops-direct-role-evacuate-yazidis-iraq|accessdate=6 June 2015|agency=The Guardian|date=13 August 2014}}</ref> The United States Central Command also reported that a seventh airdrop was conducted and that to date, 114,000 meals and more than 35,000 gallons of water had been airdropped to the displaced Yazidis in the area.<ref name=CENTCOMaug13>{{cite web|title=Aug. 13: Update on Humanitarian Assistance Operations Near Sinjar, Iraq|url=http://www.centcom.mil/news/articles/aug-13-update-on-humanitarian-assistance-operations-near-sinjar|website=United States Central Command|publisher=United States Central Command|accessdate=14 August 2014}}</ref>
In a statement on 14 August 2014, [[The Pentagon]] said that the 20 US personnel who had visited the previous day had concluded that a rescue operation was probably unnecessary since there was less danger from exposure or dehydration and the Yazidis were no longer believed to be at risk of attack from ISIL. Estimates also stated that 4,000 to 5,000 people remained on the mountain, with nearly half of which being Yazidi [[herder]]s who lived there before the siege.<ref name=WP14aug1>{{cite news|last1=DeYoung|first1=Karen|last2=Whitlock|first2=Craig|title=Rescue mission for Yazidis on Iraq's Mount Sinjar appears unnecessary, Pentagon says|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/2014/08/13/5fdd3358-2301-11e4-86ca-6f03cbd15c1a_story.html||accessdate=6 June 2015|work=The Washington Post|date=14 August 2014}}</ref><ref name=WP14aug2>{{cite news|last1=Sly|first1=Liz|last2=Whitlock|first2=Craig|title=Most Yazidis have been rescued from a besieged mountain in northern Iraq|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/yazidis-still-reported-trapped-on-mountain-in-northern-iraq-despite-us-assessment/2014/08/14/d85337fb-c5d2-4b82-b53a-410467e0db90_story.html?hpid=z2|accessdate=14 August 2014|work=The Washington Post|date=14 August 2014}}</ref><ref name=FN-20130830/>
Kurdish officials and Yazidi refugees stated that thousands of young, elderly, and disabled individuals on the mountain were still vulnerable, with the governor of Kurdistan's [[Dahuk|Dahuk province]], [[Farhad Atruchi]], saying that the assessment was "not correct" and that although people were suffering, "the international community is not moving".<ref name=WP14aug2/>
===International bodies=== * {{flag|United Nations}} – On 13 August 2014, the United Nations declared the Yazidi crisis a highest-level "Level 3 Emergency", saying that the declaration "will facilitate mobilization of additional resources in goods, funds and assets to ensure a more effective response to the humanitarian needs of populations affected by forced displacements".<ref name=FN-20130830>{{cite news|title=UN declares highest-level humanitarian emergency in Iraq as clashes erupt near Baghdad|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2014/08/14/un-declares-highest-level-humanitarian-emergency-in-iraq|accessdate=30 August 2014|work=[[Fox News]]|date=14 August 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=UN Declares a 'Level 3 Emergency' for Iraq to Ensure More Effective Humanitarian Response|url=http://www.uniraq.org/index.php?option=com_k2&view=item&id=2384:un-declares-a-level-3-emergency-for-iraq-to-ensure-more-effective-humanitarian-response&Itemid=605&lang=en|date=14 August 2014|publisher=United Nations Iraq|accessdate=14 August 2014}}</ref> On 19 March 2015, a United Nations panel concluded that ISIL "may have committed" genocide against the Yazidis with an investigation head, Suki Nagra, stating that the attacks on the Yazidis "were not just spontaneous or happened out of the blue, they were clearly orchestrated".<ref name=NYT19march15>{{cite news|last1=Cumming-Bruce|first1=Nick|title=ISIS Suspected of Genocide Against Yazidis in Iraq, U.N. Panel Says|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/20/world/middleeast/isis-genocide-yazidis-iraq-un-panel.html?WT.nav=top-news&action=click&gwt=pay&module=second-column-region&pgtype=Homepage&region=top-news&_r=0|accessdate=19 March 2015|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=19 March 2015}}</ref> * {{flag|Arab League}} – On 11 August 2014, the [[Arab League]] accused ISIL of committing [[crimes against humanity]] by persecuting the Yazidis.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_6E1UdhJI4A |title=Mid Day News – 11/08/2014 - التطورات في العراق |publisher=YouTube |date=11 August 2014|accessdate=18 August 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Addamah|first1=Steven|title=MENA: Arab league accuses ISIS of "crimes against humanity"|url=http://medafricatimes.com/3105-mena-arab-league-accuses-isis-of-crimes-against-humanity.html|date=12 August 2014|accessdate=6 June 2015|publisher=Medafrica times}}</ref> * [[Defend International]] – On 6 September 2014, Defend International launched a worldwide campaign entitled "Save The Yazidis: The World Has To Act Now" to raise awareness about the tragedy of the Yazidis in Sinjar; coordinate activities related to intensifying efforts aimed at rescuing Yazidi and Christian women and girls captured by ISIL; provide a platform for discussion and the exchange of information on matters and activities relevant to securing the fundamental rights of the Yazidis, no matter where they reside; and building a bridge between potential partners and communities whose work is relevant to the campaign, including individuals, groups, communities, and organizations active in the areas of women's and girls' rights, inter alia, as well as actors involved in ending modern-day slavery and violence against women and girls.<ref name="defendinternational.org" /><ref>{{cite web|url=https://janeadamsart.wordpress.com/about/|title= Artist Jane Adams invited to join Save The Yazidis campaign |date= |accessdate=29 September 2015}}</ref>
===Turkish aid=== Thousands of Yazidis have taken refuge in neighboring [[Turkey]], where they are being sheltered in refugee camps in the Turkish city of [[Silopi]].<ref name= DEMOTIX>{{cite web|last=Dingemans |first=Guido |url=http://www.demotix.com/news/5491116/iraqi-yezidi-refugees-flee-turkey-escape-isis-militants#media-5491092|title=Iraqi Yezidi refugees flee to Turkey to escape ISIS militants|publisher=Demotix.com|date=9 August 2014|accessdate=6 June 2015}}</ref><ref name=naharnet>{{cite web|author=music66|url=http://www.naharnet.com/stories/en/142273|title=Turkey Gives Sanctuary to Hundreds of Yazidis Fleeing Iraq|publisher=Naharnet.com|date=7 August 2014|accessdate=6 June 2015}}</ref> The Turkish Disaster Relief Agency (AFAD) has begun preparations to set up camps for receiving 6,000 refugees from Iraq.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aktifhaber.com/isid-150-bin-kisiyi-yerinden-etti-1029666h.htm|title=IŞİD 150 Bin Kişiyi Yerinden Etti|publisher=Aktif Haber|date=11 August 2014|accessdate=18 August 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140815042658/http://www.aktifhaber.com/isid-150-bin-kisiyi-yerinden-etti-1029666h.htm|archivedate=15 August 2014}}</ref> The number of Yazidi refugees in Turkey had reached 14 thousand by 30 August.<ref>[[Hürriyet]] newspaper, 31 August 2014. P.8.</ref>. However, Turkish forces have been backing the Jihadist of ISIL and displacing the Yazidi from their original villages to the city of Afrin. Furthermore, the controversy lingers after the 2014 attack on Mount Sinjar, the Turkish forces attacked the Yazidi tribe from above. Additionally, their aid was only given after many nations called out their actions that their slow movement.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.jpost.com/Middle-East/Yazidis-who-once-fled-ISIS-now-flee-Turkish-offensive-545262|title=YAZIDIS WHO ONCE FLED ISIS NOW FLEE TURKISH OFFENSIVE|last=FRANTZMAN|first=SETH|date=16 March 2018|website=Jerusalem Post|archive-url=|archivedate=|dead-url=|accessdate=15 October 2018}}</ref>
Turkish newspaper ''[[Today's Zaman]]'' claimed Turkey has also airdropped humanitarian aid to Yazidi refugees within Iraq, but Kurdish authorities didn't confirm humanitarian aid.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.todayszaman.com/diplomacy_davutoglu-turkish-aid-air-dropped-to-yazidis-in-sinjar-mountains_354865.html |title=Davutoğlu: Turkish aid air-dropped to Yazidis in Sinjar mountains |work=Today's Zaman |date=7 August 2014 |accessdate=18 August 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140816223430/http://www.todayszaman.com/diplomacy_davutoglu-turkish-aid-air-dropped-to-yazidis-in-sinjar-mountains_354865.html |archivedate=16 August 2014 }}</ref>
In August 2018, the Turkish led an Airstrike a man known as Zaki Shingali was the target who is considred to be a champion to the Yazidis.<ref name=":0" /> The Kurdistan Workers’ Party, maintains control of Sinjar mountains, the land of the Yazidis came to the aid of the Yazidi. The organization, also known as the P.K.K., established a security corridor that allowed civilians to flee the area of the massacre.<ref name=":0" /> However, the presence of the P.K.K has created a complicated dynamic, because they have continued to carry out airstrikes and take refugee in that area. Therefore, the Turkish aid is a complicated and is not always perceived as aid to the Yazidi people.
===International recognition=== [[Armenia]] became the first nation to recognise the crime against humanity perpetrated by ISIL.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.france24.com/en/20180116-armenia-recognises-genocide-yazidis-iraq/|title=Armenia Recognises Genocide of Yazidis in Iraq |date= |accessdate=16 January 2018}}</ref> The UN recognized the genocide as ongoing, however, the international community still must recognize the detrimental effects of the genocide. While some countries may choose to overlook the idea of the genocide, the UN writes that the atrocities need to be understood and the international community needs to bring the killings to an end.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://news.un.org/en/story/2017/08/562772-isils-genocide-against-yazidis-ongoing-un-rights-panel-says-calling|title=ISIL's 'genocide' against Yazidis is ongoing, UN rights panel says, calling for international action|last=|first=|date=|website=United Nations|archive-url=|archivedate=|dead-url=|accessdate=14 October 2018}}</ref> Recently, the Security Council team has enforced the idea of a new accountability team that will collect evidence of the international crimes committed by the Islamic State. However, the international community has not been in full support of this idea, because it can sometimes oversee the crimes that other armed groups are involved in.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://academic.oup.com/jicj/article-abstract/16/1/113/4925396?redirectedFrom=fulltext|title=The Iraq Investigative Team and Prospects for Justice for the Yazidi Genocide|last=Schaack|first=Beth Van|date=|website=Oxford Academic|archive-url=|archivedate=|dead-url=|accessdate=}}</ref>

{{more footnotes|date=February 2014}} [[File:Néolithique 0001.jpg|thumb|400px|An array of Neolithic artifacts, including bracelets, axe heads, chisels, and polishing tools. Neolithic stone implements are by definition polished and, except for specialty items, not chipped.]] [[Image:Molino neolítico de vaivén.jpg|thumb|A Neolithic ground stone.]] [[Image:Grinding stone.jpg|thumb|Traditional [[grinding stone]] used for making [[chutney]], [[dosa]] batter and [[idli]] batter, in [[India]] today.]]
In [[archaeology]], '''ground stone''' is a category of [[stone tool]] formed by the grinding of a coarse-grained [[tool stone]], either purposely or incidentally. Ground stone tools are usually made of [[basalt]], [[rhyolite]], [[granite]], or other [[cryptocrystalline]] and [[igneous]] stones whose coarse structure makes them ideal for grinding other materials, including plants and other stones.
== Origin == The adoption of ground [[stone technology]] is associated closely with the [[Neolithic]], also called the [[New Stone Age]]. The [[Stone Age]] comes from the three-age system developed by [[Christian Jürgensen Thomsen]]. In the Levant ground stones appear in [[Mesolithic]] 2 ([[Natufian]]). In prehistoric [[Japan]], ground stone tools appear during the [[Japanese Paleolithic]], possibly predating adoption elsewhere in the Neolithic by 25,000 years.<ref>"Prehistoric Japan, New perspectives on insular East Asia", Keiji Imamura, University of Hawaii Press, Honolulu, {{ISBN|0-8248-1853-9}}</ref>
==Creation== Ground stones were created and used for a wide variety of reasons. Each use resulted in a different development and process by which a person created their ground stone. For example, the process for creating the head of a hammer is different from the process used to create a detailed decoration piece for one’s home. That being said, there are some processes that are basic to most ground stone making.
When choosing what type of stone to use for a ground stone tool, toughness is the most important factor. If the stone is not tough enough to withstand hard hits and instead just flakes and cracks easily, the work done to create the tool has gone to waste. A stone that will not shear, flake, or crack when tested against large impacts is the most important aspect when choosing what kind of stone to use. Examples of this kind of stone include [[limestone]], [[sandstone]], [[granite]], [[basalt]], [[rhyolite]] and other [[igneous]] and [[cryptocrystalline]] rocks.
[[Cryptocrystalline]] rocks are good to use for ground stones because they have a very fine grain structure. This is helpful because the smaller the grains are in a rock, the harder the rock is.
Holes could be ground out of stones with the use of sharp pointed stones or hardened sticks. By spinning the ground stone with one's hands and applying substantial pressure to the sharp point into the ground stone, a hole could be drilled into the stone with a large amount of time and effort. Sand would be used to help quicken the process by putting it in the partially formed hole as the sharp point was being pressed. The sand would help grind more of the stone away. To put a hole all the way through a piece of stone, it would be first drilled half way in one direction and be finished on the opposite side.
Some ground stone tools are incidental, caused by use with other tools: [[Mano (stone)|manos]], for example, are hand stones used in conjunction with [[metate]]s and other [[grinding slab]]s (querns), and develop their ground surfaces through wear. Other ground stone tools include [[adze]]s, [[celt (tool)|celts]], and [[axe]]s, which are manufactured using a labor-intensive, time-consuming method of repeated grinding against a harder stone or with sand, often using water as a [[lubricant]]. These tools are often made using durable finer-grained materials rather than coarse materials. In the North American arctic, tools made of ground slate were used by the [[Norton tradition|Norton]], [[Dorset culture|Dorset]], and [[Thule people|Thule]] tool cultures, among others. Common forms of these tools were projectile points and [[ulu]]s. These tools were often purpose-made by creating a blank, either by chipping or using a technique where the slate was sawed partway through on one or both sides and then snapped into a blank, then finished by grinding with abraders or whetstones.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Clark|first1=Donald W.|title=An Example of Technological Change in Prehistory: The Origin of a Regional Ground Slate Industry in South-Central Coastal Alaska|journal=Arctic Anthropology|date=1982|volume=19|issue=1|pages=103–125|jstor=40316018}}</ref>
==Uses==
<!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:MortarandPestle.jpg|thumb|right|An ancient Mexican mortar and pestle ground stone set.]] -->
When making the head of an axe out of stone, the piece would be made so it could be hafted. In order to have the stone hafted onto a larger piece, like wood or bone, the ground stone may have at least two notches ground out of one side of the stone, making grooves for the hafting material to lie inside. These grooves would ensure that the stone would not move when struck with a large force. Tough hide would then be wound around the handle and inside the grooves, binding the ground stone and the handle together.
Ground stones were often used as dinner-ware. Using large stones, [[lithic reduction]] would be done for long periods of time to create bowls and pots for food. Jewelry, beads, ear spools and other decorative ground stones were a sign of high status due to the time and effort needed to make pieces of such small size and detail.
When mashing up seeds and leaves into powders, rounded and smooth ground stones would be used inside a stone bowl. This pair of tools is called a [[mortar and pestle]]. The material would be placed into the mortar and the pestle would be moved and pressed into the mortar to grind the material into a fine powder. This process could be used for medicine and cooking. Mortar and pestle is still used today for many cooking recipes.

[[Annemarie Bettmann]] | spouse = Charles Montgomery Gray (1954–2011)| alma_mater = [[Bryn Mawr College]], [[University of Oxford]], [[Harvard University]] }} '''Hanna Holborn Gray''' (born October 25, 1930) is an American historian of [[Renaissance]] and [[Protestant Reformation|Reformation]] political thought and Professor of History ''Emerita'' at the [[University of Chicago]]. She served as [[List of Presidents of the University of Chicago|president]] of the University of Chicago, from 1978 to 1993, having earlier served as [[List of Presidents of Yale University|acting president]] of [[Yale University]] in 1977-78. At both schools, she was the first woman to hold their highest executive office. When named to the post in Chicago, she became the first woman in the United States to hold the full presidency of a major university. ==Biography== Hanna Holborn was born in [[Heidelberg, Germany]], the daughter of [[Hajo Holborn]], a professor of European history at Yale who fled to America from [[Nazi Germany]], and Annemarie Bettmann, a philologist.{{Cite book|title=The Second Generation. Émigrés from Nazi Germany as Historians|last=Daum et al.|first=Andreas|publisher=Berghahn Books|year=2016|isbn=978-1-78238-985-9|location=New York|pages=102–113}} Her older brother, Frederick, became a White House aide and professor of foreign policy at Johns Hopkins' [[School of Advanced International Studies]].{{cite news |last=Holley |first=Joe |title=Foreign Policy Guru Frederick Holborn Dies |newspaper=Washington Post |date=9 June 2005 |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/06/08/AR2005060802579.html |accessdate=12 May 2015}} She attended The [https://www.footeschool.org/ Foote School] in New Haven, CT (graduated '43), [[Sidwell Friends School]] in Washington D.C, then [[Bryn Mawr College]] in suburban Philadelphia, where she graduated in 1950. Holborn traveled to [[Oxford University|Oxford]] as a [[Fulbright Scholar]]. She met and married Charles Montgomery Gray in 1954 while both were graduate students at [[Harvard University]], earned a [[Ph.D.]] from Harvard in 1957, and taught there, becoming an assistant professor in 1959. She moved to [[Chicago, Illinois|Chicago]] when her husband was appointed to a position at the University of Chicago. She began teaching history there and earned [[tenure]] in 1964. From 1966 to 1970, she was co-editor of the ''[[Journal of Modern History]]'' with her husband.[http://president.uchicago.edu/directory/hanna-holborn-gray "Hanna Holborn Gray", Office of the President, University of Chicago] Gray rose to prominence as an administrator after she was appointed to a committee to investigate whether a sociology professor had been denied tenure because of her gender and political sympathies. Gray was named dean of the College of Arts and Sciences at [[Northwestern University]] in 1972 and became professor of history and provost at [[Yale University]] in 1974.Kelley, Brooks Mather. (1999). [https://books.google.com/books?id=B2aDRhohtx8C&client=firefox-a ''Yale: A History.''] New Haven: [[Yale University Press]]. {{ISBN|978-0-300-07843-5}}; [http://www.worldcat.org/wcpa/oclc/810552 OCLC 810552] She served as acting president of Yale for fourteen months after President Kingman Brewster unexpectedly accepted an appointment as [[United States Ambassador to the United Kingdom|United States Ambassador to the Court of St. James's]].Leavitt, Judith A. (1985). ''American women managers and administrators,'' pp. 90-91. Gray then returned to the University of Chicago, serving as president from 1978 to 1993, the first female (full) president of a major university in the United States.For a discussion of Dr. Gray's presidency see "Hanna Holborn Gray, 1978-93," ''News from the Department of History'', University of Chicago [http://www-news.uchicago.edu/president/history/gray.shtml] She retired in June 1993 but remains [[Harry Pratt Judson]] Distinguished Service Professor ''Emerita'', continuing to offer advanced undergraduate and graduate courses in history. Her husband died in April 2011. Gray has also served as a director, board member or trustee of many institutions, including the [[Harvard Corporation]], the [[Yale Corporation]], the [[Smithsonian Institution]], [[JP Morgan Chase]], the [[Andrew W. Mellon Foundation]], the Marlboro School of Music, the [[Council on Foreign Relations]], the [[Concord Coalition]], the [[Mayo Clinic]], the [[Brookings Institution]], and [[Bryn Mawr College]]. Gray has received honorary degrees from more than sixty institutions, including the University of Chicago, [[The College of William and Mary]], Harvard, Oxford, Yale, [[Brown University|Brown]], [[Columbia University|Columbia]], [[Princeton University|Princeton]], and [[Duke University|Duke]]. She served as chairman of the board of the second largest foundation in America, the [[Howard Hughes Medical Institute]], until 2010.http://www.hhmi.org/news/20100610.html The portrait of Hanna Gray that hangs at the University of Chicago has been stolen on more than one occasion as a prank.[http://magazine.uchicago.edu/9608/9608JournalPortrait.html University of Chicago Magazine] Gray published a memoir {{cite book| url=https://press.princeton.edu/titles/11244.html| title=An Academic Life |publisher= Princeton University Press| year=2018| isbn= 9780691179186 }} ==Honors== * [[Medal of Liberty]] * [[Presidential Medal of Freedom]] * [[Francis Boyer Award]] ==Chronology== *Teaching Fellow, Harvard University, 1955–1957 *Instructor, Harvard University, 1957–1959 *Assistant Professor, Harvard University, 1959–1960 *Assistant Professor of History at the University of Chicago 1961-1964 *Associate Professor of History at the University of Chicago 1964-1972 *Professor and Dean, Northwestern University 1972-1974 *Professor and Provost at Yale University 1974-1978 *Acting President of Yale University 1977-1978 *Professor of History at the University of Chicago 1978–present *President of the University of Chicago 1978-1993 *Appointed to the Harvard Corporation, 1997 == Works and publications == * Hanna Holborn Gray, "Some Reflections on the Second Generation." ''The Second Generation. Émigrés from Nazi Germany as Historians'', ed. Andreas Daum, Harmut Lehmann, and James J. Sheehan. {{Infobox language |name=Hawaiʻi Sign Language |altname=Hoailona ʻŌlelo o Hawaiʻi |states=[[United States]] |region=[[Hawaii]] |speakers=30; virtually extinct; a few elderly signers are [[bilingual]] with the dominant [[American Sign Language|ASL]] <ref>http://www.endangeredlanguages.com/lang/4275</ref> |date=2013 |ref=<ref name="hsl" /> |familycolor=sign |family=Isolate |iso3=hps |glotto=hawa1235 |glottorefname=Hawai'i Pidgin Sign Language; Pidgin Sign Language }}
'''Hawaiʻi Sign Language''' (HSL), also known as '''Old Hawaiʻi Sign Language''' and '''Pidgin Sign Language''' (PSL),<ref>[http://www.endangeredlanguages.com/lang/4275 "Hawai'i Sign Language"]. ''http://www.endangeredlanguages.com/lang/4275''. Retrieved April 30, 2017.</ref> is an indigenous [[sign language]] used in [[Hawaii|Hawaiʻi]]. Although historical records document its presence on the islands as early as the 1820s, it was not formally recognized until 2013 by linguists at the University of Hawai'i.<ref name=hsl> {{cite news |title=Linguists say Hawaii Sign Language found to be distinct language |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/higher-education/linguists-say-hawaii-sign-language-found-to-be-distinct-language/2013/03/01/bbca83cc-82d6-11e2-a671-0307392de8de_story.html |accessdate=9 March 2013 |newspaper=Washington Post |date=1 March 2013}} </ref> It is the first new language to be uncovered within the [[United States]] since the 1930s.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://rosettaproject.org/blog/02013/mar/8/linguists-discover-existence-distinct-hawaiian-sig/|title=Linguists Discover Existence of Distinct Hawaiian Sign Language - The Rosetta Project|website=rosettaproject.org|access-date=2016-04-28}}</ref> Linguistic experts believe HSL may be the last undiscovered language in the country.<ref>Wilcox, D. (n.d.). [https://kealakai.byuh.edu/content/linguists-rediscover-hawaiian-sign-language Linguists rediscover Hawaiian Sign Language]. Retrieved April 30, 2017</ref>
Although previously believed to be related to [[American Sign Language]] (ASL),<ref>[[Henri Wittmann|Wittmann, Henri]] (1991). "Classification linguistique des langues signées non vocalement." ''Revue québécoise de linguistique théorique et appliquée'' 10:1.215–88.[http://www.nou-la.org/ling/1991a-class.pdf]</ref> the two languages are in fact unrelated.<ref name="LambrechtEarthWoodward">{{citation|last=Lambrecht|first=Linda|title=History and Documentation of Hawaiʻi Sign Language: First Report|date=March 3, 2013|url=http://hdl.handle.net/10125/26133|last2=Earth|last3=Woodward|first2=Barbara|first3=James|place=University of Hawaiʻi|publisher=3rd International Conference on Language Documentation and Conservation}} </ref><ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=Rarrick|first=Samantha|last2=Labrecht|first2=Linda|date=2016|title=Hawai'i Sign Language|url=|journal=The SAGE Deaf Studies Encyclopedia|volume=|pages=781–785|via=}}</ref> The initial research team interviewed 19 Deaf people and two children of Deaf parents on four islands.<ref>Lincoln, M. (2013, March 01). [http://www.hawaiinewsnow.com/story/21440949/nearly-lost-language-discovered-in-hawaii Nearly lost language discovered in Hawai'i]. Retrieved April 30, 2017</ref> It was found that eighty percent of HSL vocabulary is different than [[American Sign Language]], proving that HSL is an independent language.<ref name=":5">Clark, B., Lambrecht, L., Rarrick, S., Stabile, C., & Woodward, J. (2013). [http://ling.hawaii.edu/wp-content/uploads/ABSTRACT-FOR-DOCUMENTATION-OF-HAWAII-SIGN-LANGUAGE.pdf <nowiki>DOCUMENTATION OF HAWAI`I SIGN LANGUAGE: AN OVERVIEW OF SOME RECENT MAJOR RESEARCH FINDINGS [Abstract]</nowiki>]. ''University of Hawai'i,'' 1-2. Retrieved April 30, 2017</ref> Additionally, there is a HSL-ASL creole, Creole Hawai'i Sign Language (CHSL) which is used by approximately 40 individuals in the generations between those who signed HSL exclusively and those who sign ASL exclusively.<ref name=":6">{{Cite journal|last=Clark, Brenda; Samantha Rarrick; Bradley Rentz; Claire Stabile; James Woodward & Sarah Uno|first=|date=2016|title=Uncovering Creole Hawai'i Sign Language: Evidence from a case study|url=|journal=Theoretical Issues in Sign Language Research (TISLR) 12|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> However, since the 1940s ASL has almost fully replaced the use of HSL on the islands of Hawai'i <ref name=":0" /> and CHSL is likely to also be lost in the next 50 years.<ref name=":6" />
Prior to the recognition of HSL as a distinct language in 2013, it was an undocumented language.<ref name="race">{{Cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/news/2016/aug/10/race-to-save-hawaii-sign-language | title=The Race to Save a Dying Language |last=Perlin |first=Ross |publisher=[[Guardian Media Group]] |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=August 10, 2016}}</ref> HSL is at risk of [[Language extinction|extinction]] due to its low number of signers and the adoption of [[ASL]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://manoa.hawaii.edu/news/article.php?aId=5600/|title=Mānoa: Research team discovers existence of Hawai'i Sign Language {{!}} University of Hawaii News|website=manoa.hawaii.edu|access-date=2016-04-28}}</ref> With fewer than 30 signers remaining worldwide, HSL is considered [[Endangered language|critically endangered]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.endangeredlanguages.com/lang/4275|title=Did you know Hawai'i Sign Language is critically endangered?|website=Endangered Languages|access-date=2016-04-28}}</ref> Without documentation and revitalization efforts, such as the ongoing efforts initiated by Dr. James Woodward, Dr. Barbara Earth, and Linda Lambrecht,<ref name=":4" /> this language may become dormant or extinct.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://multitree.org/codes/hps|title=Hawai'i Sign Language - MultiTree|website=multitree.org|access-date=2016-04-28}}</ref>
== Discovery == HSL was recognized by linguists on March 1, 2013 by a research group from the [[University of Hawaii at Manoa|University of Hawai'i at Manoa]]. The research team found a letter from [[Hiram Bingham I|Reverend Hiram Bingham]] to [[Thomas Hopkins Gallaudet|Reverend Thomas H. Gallaudet]] from Feb. 23, 1821. The letter described several instances of Deaf natives communicating to Bingham in their own sign language.<ref name="LambrechtEarthWoodward" /> At the time of discovery, the language was used by around 40 people, mostly over 80-years-old.<ref>Mcavoy, A. (2013, March 01). [http://www.staradvertiser.com/2013/03/01/breaking-news/hawaii-sign-language-found-to-be-distinct-language/ Hawaii Sign Language found to be distinct language]. ''Associated Press''. Retrieved April 30, 2017</ref> [[File:DiscoveryHSL.jpg|none|thumb|Bingham letter]]
== History == HSL is not itself a [[pidgin]],<ref name="Ethnologue">{{citation|title=Ethnologue|url=http://www.ethnologue.com/language/hps}} </ref> but alternate names for the language are documented as Hawai'i Pidgin Sign Language or Pidgin Sign Language.<ref name=":2" /> This is due to to an inaccurate historical association with the spoken language [[Hawaii Pidgin|Hawaiʻi Pidgin]]. Linguists who have begun to document the language and community members prefer the name ''Hawaiʻi Sign Language'',<ref name=":4" /><ref name="LambrechtEarthWoodward" /> and that is the name used for it in [[ISO 639-3]] as of 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www-01.sil.org/iso639-3/documentation.asp?id=hps|title=Documentation for ISO 639 identifier: hps|accessdate=2014-02-07}}</ref>
Village sign use, by both d/Deaf and hearing, is attested from 1820. There's the possibility of influence from immigrant sign later that century, though HSL has little in common today with ASL or other signed and spoken languages it has come in contact with. The establishment of a school for the deaf in 1914 strengthened the use of sign, primarily HSL, among the students. A Deaf community hero, a Chinese-Hawai'ian Deaf man named Edwin Inn, taught HSL to other d/Deaf adults and also stood as president of a Deaf club.<ref name=":1" /> However, the introduction of ASL in 1941 in place of purely oral instruction resulted in a shift from HSL.
== HSL and ASL Comparisons == HSL shares few lexical and grammatical components with ASL.<ref name=":4" /><ref name="LambrechtEarthWoodward" /><ref name="hsl" /><ref name=":3">Tanigawa, N. (2016, NOV 22). [http://hawaiipublicradio.org/post/hawai-i-sign-language-still-whispers Hawai'i Sign Language Still Whispers]. Retrieved May 1, 2017</ref> While HSL follows subject, object, verb (SOV) typology, ASL follows subject, verb, object (SVO) typology.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.ethnologue.com/language/hps|title=Hawaii Sign Language|work=Ethnologue|access-date=2018-02-09|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.ethnologue.com/language/ase|title=American Sign Language|work=Ethnologue|access-date=2018-02-09|language=en}}</ref> HSL does not have verbal classifiers- these were previously thought to be universal in sign languages, and ASL makes extensive use of these.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Rarrick|first=Samantha|date=2015|title=A Sketch of Handshape Morphology in Hawai'i Sign Language|url=http://ling.hawaii.edu/wp-content/uploads/wp-rarrick.pdf|journal=University of Hawai'i at Manoa Working Papers in Linguistics|volume=46 |issue=6|pages=|via=}}</ref> HSL also has several entirely non-manual lexical items, including verbs and nouns, which are not typical in ASL.<ref name=":5" /> Ongoing investigation of these languages suggest that they are not related.<ref name=":4" />
== HSL Today == An estimated 15,857 of the total 833,610 residents of Hawai'i (about 1.9%) are audiologically [[deaf]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://libguides.gallaudet.edu/content.php?pid=119476&sid=1029190|title=LibGuides. Deaf Statistics. Deaf population of the U.S..|last=Smith|first=Sarah Hamrick, Laura Jacobi, Patrick Oberholtzer, Elizabeth Henry, Jamie|website=libguides.gallaudet.edu|language=en|access-date=2016-04-28}}</ref> Among this population, ASL is now significantly more common than HSL. There are a handful of services available to help d/Deaf Hawai'ian residents learn ASL and also for those who wish to learn ASL to become interpreters, such as the Aloha State Association of the Deaf and the American Sign Language Interpreter Education Program.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.signsofself.org/html/hawaii_links.html|title=Signs of Self|website=www.signsofself.org|access-date=2016-04-28}}</ref> Equivalent services for HSL are nearly non-existent, partially because some members of the Deaf community in Hawai'i have felt that it is not worth preservation.<ref name=":3" />
Linda Lambrecht, Dr. James Woodward and Barbara Clark are continually working with a team to document and preserve the language.<ref name="race" /> Another research member, Dr. Samantha Rarrick, is part of the Sign Language Documentation Training Center at the University of Hawai'i. This group has two goals. Their first goal to teach graduate students and other linguists how to document HSL and other small sign languages used in Hawai'i.<ref>Rarrick, S., & Wilson, B. (2015). [https://scholarspace.manoa.hawaii.edu/bitstream/10125/24697/1/rarrick.pdf Documenting Hawai‘i’s Sign Languages. ''Language Documentation & Conservation'']'',10'', 337-346. Retrieved April 30, 2017</ref> Their second goal is to have 20-hours of translated-HSL on video.<ref name="race" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://elar.soas.ac.uk/Collection/MPI483793|title=Documentation of Hawaii Sign Language: Building the Foundation for Documentation, Conservation, and Revitalization of Endangered Pacific Island Sign Languages.|last=|first=|date=|website=Endangered Languages Archive at SOAS University of London|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=July 12, 2017}}</ref> As of Nov. 22, 2016, a dictionary and video archive of speakers have been created.<ref name=":3" />

MultiTree: A Digital Library of Language Relationships] * [http://www.signsofself.org/html/hawaii_links.html Hawaii Links & Resources. (2016) * ''Ice Age - Geode Jam!'' (2016) * ''Ice Age - Coloring Book'' (2016) * ''Ice Age - Matching Cards'' (2016) |soundtracks = * ''[[Ice Age (2002 film)#Soundtrack|Ice Age]]'' * ''[[Ice Age: The Meltdown#Soundtrack|Ice Age: The Meltdown]]'' * ''[[Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs#Soundtrack|Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs]]'' * ''[[Ice Age: Continental Drift#Soundtrack|Ice Age: Continental Drift]]'' * ''[[Ice Age: Collision Course#Soundtrack|Ice Age: Collision Course]]'' }} '''''Ice Age''''' is an American [[media franchise]] centering on a group of [[mammal]]s surviving the [[Paleolithic]] [[ice age]]. It is produced by [[Blue Sky Studios]], a division of [[20th Century Fox]], and featuring the voices of [[Ray Romano]], [[John Leguizamo]], [[Denis Leary]], and [[Chris Wedge]]. Five films have been released in the series thus far with ''[[Ice Age (2002 film)|Ice Age]]'' in 2002, ''[[Ice Age: The Meltdown]]'' in 2006, ''[[Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs]]'' in 2009, ''[[Ice Age: Continental Drift]]'' in 2012, and ''[[Ice Age: Collision Course]]'' in 2016. It has received some criticism for making no attempt to be scientifically accurate.{{cite web|url=http://sacramentopress.com/2012/07/13/avoid-ice-age-continental-drift-and-seek-out-the-japanese-film-festival/|title=Avoid "Ice Age: Continental Drift" and seek out the Japanese film festival|first=Tony|last=Sheppard|publisher=Sacramento Press|date=July 13, 2012|accessdate=July 17, 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://blog.sfgate.com/parenting/2009/07/01/ice-age-dawn-of-the-scientific-inaccuracies/|title=Ice Age: Dawn of the Scientific Inaccuracies?|first=Peter|last=Hartlaub|publisher=SF Gate|date=July 1, 2009|accessdate=July 17, 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/erickohn/status/753691627215056896|title=Comment on Tyson's appearance|first=Eric|last=Kohn|publisher=Twitter|date=July 14, 2016|accessdate=July 17, 2016}} As of April 2016, the franchise had generated $6 billion in revenue,{{cite web|last1=Wilonsky|first1=Robert|last2=Engel|first2=Clint|url=http://www.furnituretoday.com/article/530876-ashley-ikidz-retailers-get-promotion-latest-ice-age-movie|title=Clint Engel Ashley iKidz retailers get promotion for latest 'Ice Age' movie|magazine=[[Furniture Today]]|publisher=Sandow Media|date=April 25, 2016|accessdate=July 18, 2017}} making it one of the [[List of the highest-grossing media franchises|highest-grossing media franchises of all time]]. ==Films== ===''Ice Age'' (2002)=== {{Main|Ice Age (2002 film)}} Sid, a talkative sloth, is left behind by his family and the herds of mammals journeying to the south. He meets Manny, a mammoth who travels to the north, and decides to follow him. When a humans' camp is attacked by tigers, a woman takes her baby and jumps into a river and falls over a waterfall. Before she disappears, the baby is rescued by Manny and Sid. The two animals decide to search for the father and return the baby to him. Diego, one of the tigers that attacked the humans, comes also claiming the baby, and the trio form an uneasy alliance during their journey to the humans. ===''Ice Age: The Meltdown'' (2006)=== {{Main|Ice Age: The Meltdown}} Manny, Sid, and Diego are currently living in a large valley surrounded by an enormously high ice wall on all sides. However, the trio discovers that the ice wall is actually a wall that is barely holding a massive body of water that could flood the valley to nearly a mile underwater. A vulture tells them that there is a boat at the other end of the valley that may save them all, but they only have three days to reach it or die. Manny is also having trouble fearing the fact that he may be the last mammoth left. Along the way, they meet Ellie, a mammoth who thinks she is a possum, and her possum brothers Crash and Eddie. As they begin to travel together, Manny learns, with help from Diego and Sid, that he must move on from his past. During their journey, [[Scrat]] the sabre-toothed squirrel has his own adventure. ===''Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs'' (2009)=== {{Main|Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs}} Manny and Ellie are expecting their first child, meanwhile Scrat falls in love with fellow squirrel Scratte. Meanwhile, Diego is anxious about settling down for a domestic life with Manny's new family. Sid begins to wish for a family of his own, and steals some dinosaur eggs which leads to Sid ending up in a strange underground world where his herd must rescue him. The herd also meets an insane one-eyed weasel known as Buck who aids them on their quest. ===''Ice Age: Continental Drift'' (2012)=== {{Main|Ice Age: Continental Drift}} Taking place several years after the events of the third film, with Peaches now a teenager, Scrat's pursuit of acorns has world-changing consequences, separating Manny, Sid and Diego from the rest of their group. As they try to return home, they come into conflict with a pirate gang led by Captain Gutt. === {{anchor|Ice_Age_5_.282016.29}}''Ice Age: Collision Course'' (2016) === {{Main|Ice Age: Collision Course}} Set after the events of ''[[Ice Age: Continental Drift|Continental Drift]]'', Scrat's pursuit of his elusive acorn catapults him outside of Earth aboard a UFO, where he accidentally sets off a series of cosmic events that transform and threaten the planet. To save themselves from peril, Manny, Sid, Diego, and the rest of the herd leave their home and reunite with Buck, who leads them on a journey to find a way to save the planet. ===Future=== On the possibility of a potential sequel to ''[[Ice Age: Collision Course]]'', in June 2016, Galen T. Chu, co-director of the film, stated that there were some ideas for the next installment.{{cite web|url=https://www.flickreel.com/ice-age-collision-course-interview-with-co-director-galen-t-chu/|title=ICE AGE: COLLISION COURSE INTERVIEW WITH CO-DIRECTOR GALEN T. CHU|author=Cassam Looch|work=Flickreel|date=June 27, 2016|accessdate=July 16, 2016}} In July 2016, Bustle noted that the potential of ''Ice Age 6'' actually being produced was relatively high even though it could largely depend on the box office performance of the fifth film.{{cite web|url=https://www.bustle.com/articles/172484-will-there-be-another-ice-age-movie-this-franchise-is-staying-strong|title=Will There Be Another Ice Age Movie? This Franchise Is Staying Strong|author=Johnny Brayson|work=Bustle|date=July 21, 2016|accessdate=April 18, 2018}} PopWrapped later commented in February 2017, on the fifth film's poor reception and how the franchise was moving further into absurdity and further away from leaving any lasting emotional impact on the audience, and stated that the sixth film could have potential to redeem the franchise by going back to its roots and reintroducing the humans from the original film, particularly the little baby named Roshan, and thereby bring the audience to remember why they loved ''Ice Age'' so much in the first place, and perhaps end the series on a high note.{{cite web|url=https://popwrapped.com/ice-age-6|title=Why There Should Be An 'Ice Age 6' And How To Make It Great|author=Landon Abernathy|work=PopWrapped|date=February 18, 2017|accessdate=April 18, 2018}} ==Short films== ===''Gone Nutty''=== {{main|Gone Nutty}} ''Gone Nutty'' is a 2002 animated short film, directed by [[Carlos Saldanha]], and originally released on the ''Ice Age'' DVD.{{cite web|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,393167,00.html?xid=rss-allabout-MovieIceAge-Ice+Age|title=Ice Age DVD review|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|date=November 29, 2002|accessdate=August 9, 2011|last=Fretts|first=Bruce}} The short features the character Scrat, who is yet again having troubles with collecting his beloved acorns. The film was nominated for the [[76th Academy Awards|2003]] [[Academy Award for Best Animated Short Film|Academy Award for Animated Short Film]].{{cite news|title=The 76th Academy Awards (2004) Nominees and Winners |url=http://www.oscars.org/awards/academyawards/legacy/ceremony/76th-winners.html |accessdate=July 24, 2012 |newspaper=The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences |date=February 29, 2004 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6BQv3CYAA?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.oscars.org%2Fawards%2Facademyawards%2Flegacy%2Fceremony%2F76th-winners.html |archivedate=October 15, 2012 |df=mdy-all }} ===''No Time for Nuts''=== {{main|No Time for Nuts}} ''No Time for Nuts'' is a 2006 animated short film, directed by [[Chris Renaud (animator)|Chris Renaud]] and [[Mike Thurmeier]], and it was originally released on the ''Ice Age: The Meltdown'' DVD.{{cite web|url=http://www.blueskystudios.com/content/shorts-notimefornuts.php|title=No Time for Nuts|publisher=[[Blue Sky Studios]]|accessdate=August 9, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120716225206/http://blueskystudios.com/content/shorts-notimefornuts.php|archivedate=July 16, 2012|df=mdy-all}} The short follows Scrat on a chase after his nut, which has been accidentally sent back in time by a frozen time machine. ''No Time for Nuts'' was nominated for the [[79th Academy Awards|2007]] [[Academy Award for Best Animated Short Film]].{{cite web|title=The 79th Academy Awards (2007) Nominees and Winners|url=http://www.oscars.org/awards/academyawards/legacy/ceremony/79th-winners.html|publisher=The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences|accessdate=April 3, 2012}} ===''Surviving Sid''=== {{main|Surviving Sid}} ''Surviving Sid'' is a 2008 animated short film, directed by Galen Tan Chu and [[Karen Disher]]. It was originally released on the ''[[Horton Hears a Who! (film)|Horton Hears a Who!]]'' DVD and Blu-ray.{{cite web|url=http://collider.com/dvd/reviews/article.asp?aid=10138&tcid=3|title=HORTON HEARS A WHO Special Edition DVD Review|publisher=Collider|date=December 14, 2008|accessdate=August 9, 2011}} Unlike the first two ''Ice Age'' short films, ''Surviving Sid'' focuses on Sid, who incompetently "leads" a small group of camping children. ===''Scrat's Continental Crack-Up''=== ''Scrat's Continental Crack-Up'' is the first of a 2012 two-part animated short. ===''Scrat's Continental Crack-Up: Part 2''=== ''Scrat's Continental Crack-Up: Part 2'' is the second of a 2012 two-part animated short. ===''Cosmic Scrat-tastrophe''=== {{main|Cosmic Scrat-tastrophe}} ''Cosmic Scrat-tastrophe'' is a 2015 animated short film. The short once again follows Scrat, who discovers a flying saucer frozen in a block of ice and accidentally powers it on and ends up creating the Solar System through a series of mishaps. ===''Scrat: Spaced Out''=== {{main|Scrat: Spaced Out}} ''Scrat: Spaced Out'' is a 2016 animated short film. The short once again follows Scrat, trying to get back to Earth after the events in ''Cosmic Scrat-tastrophe''. ==Television== ===Specials=== ====''Ice Age: A Mammoth Christmas''==== {{main|Ice Age: A Mammoth Christmas}} In the middle of decorating for the holiday season, Sid accidentally destroys Manny's favourite decorations. Sid, convinced by Manny that he is now on Santa's naughty list, takes off with Crash, Eddie and Peaches for the North Pole to get back on the Santa's good side. When on the North Pole, Sid and his crew accidentally destroy Santa's Workshop. When Manny, Ellie and Diego, worried over Peaches's safety, arrive at the North Pole, they must come together and save Christmas.{{cite web|title=Ice Age - Mammoth Christmas (TBA): DVD|url=http://www.dvdwarehouse.com.au/ice-age-mammoth-christmas-9321337132020.html|work=DVD Warehouse|accessdate=September 29, 2011}} ====''Ice Age: The Great Egg-Scapade''==== {{main|Ice Age: The Great Egg-Scapade}} The special centers on a harried prehistoric bird mom who entrusts her precious, soon-to-hatch egg to Sid. When she recommends him to her neighbors—a condor mother, Cholly Bear and Gladys Glypto—business booms at his new egg-sitting service. However, dastardly pirate bunny Squint, who is seeking revenge on the herd, steals, camouflages and hides all the eggs. Once again, with Squint’s twin brother, Clint, assisting, Manny, Diego and the rest of the gang come to the rescue and take off on a daring mission that turns into the world’s first Easter egg hunt. ===Television series=== CEO of 20th Century Fox [[Stacey Snider]] announced that a television series based on ''Ice Age'' is currently being developed. With the [[Proposed acquisition of 21st Century Fox by Disney|upcoming acquisition by Disney]], it is possible that it will appear on one of their platforms.{{cite web|url=http://www.comingsoon.net/tv/news/965417-fox-developing-wimpy-kid-ice-age-and-night-at-the-museum-tv-shows|title=Fox Developing Wimpy Kid, Ice Age, and Night at the Museum TV Shows|website=Coming Soon.net|last=Paz|first=Maggie Dela|date=August 10, 2018|accessdate=August 11, 2018}} ==Cast== {{Further|List of Ice Age characters}} ===Feature films=== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" width=100% ! rowspan="3" | Characters ! align="center" width="17%" | ''[[Ice Age (2002 film)|Ice Age]]'' ! align="center" width="17%" | ''[[Ice Age: The Meltdown|{{small|Ice Age:}}

Matching Cards'' was an online game released in 2016. ==Live show== ''Ice Age Live! A Mammoth Adventure'' is a live arena [[ice show]] that combines ice skating, aerial arts, puppetry and film, and tells a new story based on the first three ''Ice Age'' films.{{cite news|title=Ice Age Live! A Mammoth Adventure is Coming in 2012|url=http://www.comingsoon.net/news/movienews.php?id=84761|accessdate=December 1, 2011|newspaper=Twentieth Century Fox Consumer Products ''via'' Comingsoon.net|date=December 1, 2011}} The plot begins with baby mammoth Peaches being kidnapped by an evil hawk-like creature called Shadow. Her father Manny sets off to rescue Peaches, accompanied by Sid and Diego. Their mission is successful, but on the way home they encounter avalanches and rockfalls, diverting them into a fantasy underground kingdom.{{cite news|last=Dalton|first=Stephen|title=Ice Age Live! A Mammoth Adventure: Theater Review|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/review/ice-age-live-a-mammoth-386246|accessdate=November 7, 2012|newspaper=The Hollywood Reporter|date=November 3, 2012}} It is being produced by Stage Entertainment Touring Productions, and directed by Guy Caron and Michael Curry. The music and lyrics were written by Ella Louise Allaire and Martin Lord Ferguson. With the preview shows from October 19 to 21, 2012, in [[Cardiff]], and from October 25 to 28, 2012, in [[Nottingham]], ''A Mammoth Adventure'' officially premiered on November 2, 2012,{{cite news|last=Langsworthy|first=Billy|title=BLE 2012: Five-year Ice Age Live tour unveiled|url=http://www.licensing.biz/news/10115/BLE-20th-Century-Fox-announce-five-year-Ice-Age-Live-tour|accessdate=October 23, 2012|newspaper=Licensing.biz|date=October 18, 2012}} during its three-day tour from November 1 to 3 at [[Wembley Arena]] in London.{{cite news|title=Ice Age Live London|url=http://www.viewlondon.co.uk/whatson/ice-age-live-london-article-11466.html|accessdate=November 7, 2012|newspaper=View}} It continued in Germany in November 2012,{{cite web|title=Tour Schedule International|url=http://www.iceagelive.com/international/tour-schedule.aspx|publisher=Ice Age Live! A Mammoth Adventure|accessdate=June 25, 2012}} with a plan to visit more than 30 countries in its five-year worldwide tour. In August 2016, ''Ice Age Live! A Mammoth Adventure'' concluded its world tour and was replaced in North America by ''Ice Age On Ice''.{{cite web|url=http://iceagelive.com/iceagelivestopped/index.html|title=ICE AGE LIVE! A Mammoth Adventure|publisher=Ice Age Live|date=June 2, 2016|accessdate=October 11, 2016}} ==Themed land== ''Ice Age'' inspired rides and attractions will be featured at the first [[20th Century Fox]] theme park, called [[Twentieth Century Fox World|20th Century Fox World]],{{cite news|last=Tartaglione|first=Nancy|title=Fox Breaks Ground On Malaysia Theme Park; 20th Century Fox World To Open 2016|url=http://www.deadline.com/2013/12/fox-breaks-ground-on-malaysia-theme-park-20th-century-fox-world-to-open-2016/|accessdate=December 17, 2013|newspaper=Deadline|date=December 17, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131217111020/http://www.deadline.com/2013/12/fox-breaks-ground-on-malaysia-theme-park-20th-century-fox-world-to-open-2016/|archivedate=December 17, 2013|df=mdy-all}} to open in 2017 as part of Malaysia-based [[Genting Highlands|Resorts World Genting]].{{cite news|last=Han|first=Angie|title=Fox to Build Theme Park Featuring ‘Life of Pi’, ‘Alien’, ‘Ice Age’ Attractions|url=http://www.slashfilm.com/foxs-malaysian-theme-park-to-feature-life-of-pi-alien-ice-age-attractions/|accessdate=July 28, 2013|newspaper=/Film|date=July 26, 2013}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Ice Age (movie franchise)}} * {{Official website|http://www.iceagemovies.com/}} {{Ice Age}} {{Blue Sky Studios}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ice Age (Film Series)}} [[Category:Ice Age (franchise)| ]] [[Category:Animated film series]] [[Category:Film series]] [[Category:Film series introduced in 2002]] [[Category:20th Century Fox franchises]] [[Category:Boom! [[Image:Indian Institute.jpg|thumb|300px|Indian Institute building seen from the north-west]]
The '''Indian Institute''' in central [[Oxford]], [[England]], is at the north end of [[Catte Street]] on the corner with [[Holywell Street]] and facing down [[Broad Street, Oxford|Broad Street]] from the east.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.1911encyclopedia.org/Oxford,_England|title=1911 Encyclopedia reference on Indian Institute|accessdate=2007-03-02|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070207062738/http://www.1911encyclopedia.org/Oxford%2C_England|archivedate=2007-02-07|df=}}</ref> Sir [[Monier Monier-Williams]] started the Institute in the [[University of Oxford]] in 1883 to provide training for the [[Indian Civil Service (British India)|Indian Civil Service]] of the [[British Raj]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oxfordhistory.org.uk/broad/buildings/east/history_faculty/index.html |title=From the extract of ''Kelly's directory'' for 1900. |accessdate=2012-08-03 |df= }}{{dead link|date=May 2017|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref><ref>http://www.open.ac.uk/researchprojects/makingbritain/content/indian-institute</ref>
==History and building== [[Image:Indian Institute cupola.jpg|thumb|right|Corner cupola with elephant weathervane]] In June 1881, plans were submitted to the University of Oxford's [[Hebdomadal Council]] to build an Indian Institute. The original site was occupied by four old buildings. The building was designed by [[Basil Champneys]] and the first section opened in 1884. Originally there was a low shop to the south, but neighbouring [[Hertford College]] has now encroached on the Institute with a much taller building. The Institute was built of [[Taynton, Oxfordshire#Taynton stone|Taynton stone]] in the style of the [[English Renaissance]], with different oriental details to the designs of Champneys. In 1974 [[Nikolaus Pevsner]] observed that the rounded corner cupola made an excellent ''point de vue'' at the east end of Broad Street.
Along with the [[library]] ''(see below)'', the institute contained [[Classroom|lecture room]]s and a [[museum]]. Some contents of the museum are now present in the [[Ashmolean Museum|Ashmolean]] and [[Pitt Rivers Museum]]s. The original Indian Institute building is now the [[Oxford Martin School]] of the University of Oxford, the History Faculty having moved to the old [[City of Oxford High School for Boys|City of Oxford School]] building on [[George Street, Oxford|George Street]] and its library to the Bodleian site.
==Indian Institute Library== {{main|Indian Institute Library}} The [[Indian Institute Library]] opened in 1886. It became a dependent library of the [[Bodleian Library]], the main library of the University, in 1927. It specialises in the history and culture of [[South Asia]], especially the [[Himalayas]] and [[Tibet]].<ref>Bodleian Library: Department of Oriental Collections: 'Indian Institute Library', http://www.bodley.ox.ac.uk/dept/oriental/iil.htm, accessed 2007-02-14.</ref> The library was formerly located in the Indian Institute building, but was moved to the top floor of the New Bodleian Library.
==Indian Institute Museum== The Museum was an integral part of Monier-Williams’ design, modelled to some extent on the India Museum in South Kensington. Monier-Williams acquired some pieces during his fund-raising and collecting tour of India in 1883-1884, including from the International Exhibition, at Calcutta, and arranged for regional representatives to send objects to Oxford. Babu T.N. Mukharji was commissioned to catalogue the collections in 1886 (never finished). The installation of the museum was done by Dr [[Heinrich Lüders]], assisted by Mr. Long of the Pitt Rivers Museum, and completed in 1898. When Monier-Williams died in 1899, no financial provision had been made for running the museum. Gradually, the collections were dispersed: entomological and zoological collections to the University Museum; and many pieces to the Pitt Rivers Museum and the Ashmolean Museum. A summary catalogue of the museum was prepared by Mr A. Rost (for a short handbook to the Institute, by Prof [[Arthur Anthony Macdonell|Arthur Macdonell]], 1922, but never published).<ref>Andrew Topsfield, History of the Indian Collections, in Indian Art in the Ashmolean Museum, A catalogue of the Ashmolean’s collection of Indian art by J. C. Harle and Andrew Topsfield (published Oxford, 1987).http://jameelcentre.ashmolean.org/collection/7/10230/10260</ref>
==Accusations of racism== The building was financed entirely by private donors in India and Britain, for the sole purpose of constructing an edifice to house study for and on the Indian sub-continent. There was consequently great controversy in 1968, when the University's governing council evicted the Indian Institute from the premises without compensation, and then made a gift of the premises to the History Faculty, which specialises in European history to the exclusion of Indian history. The government of India filed a formal protest on behalf of the families of the original donors, who felt defrauded by the University's actions. The [[Oxford University Student Union]] went further still, accusing the University administration of racism in the decision.
==The Institute's aim== The aim of the Indian Institute was: :''The work of fostering and facilitating Indian studies in the University; the work of making Englishmen, and even Indians themselves, appreciate better than they have done before the languages, literature and industries of India.''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oxfordhistory.org.uk/broad/buildings/east/history_faculty/ |title=Aim of the Indian Institute |accessdate=2007-03-02 |df= }}{{dead link|date=May 2017|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>
