'''Nielsen BookScan''' has been a [[data]] provider for the [[book]] [[publishing]] industry, owned by the [[Nielsen Company]] up to 2016, though it is still in use via the [[NPD Group]]. BookScan compiles [[point of sale]] data for book sales.<ref name=Slate>[[Daniel Gross]]. "[http://www.slate.com/id/2142810/ Why writers never reveal how many books their buddies have sold]." ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]'', June 2, 2006. Retrieved on January 5, 2008.</ref><ref name=PW>Jim Milliot and Steven Zeitchik. "[http://www.publishersweekly.com/article/CA374063.html Bookscan: Acceptance, And Questions, Grow]." ''[[Publishers Weekly]]'', January 12, 2004. Retrieved on January 5, 2008.</ref><ref name=Slate2>[[Adelle Waldman]]. "[http://www.slate.com/id/2081052/ Cents and Sensibility; The surprising truth about sales of classic novels]." ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]'', April 2, 2003. Retrieved on January 5, 2008.</ref><ref name=TBS>Anna Weinberg. "[http://www.thebookstandard.com/bookstandard/news/retail/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1000989390 Nielsen BookScan Releases Potter Sales Figures]." ''The Book Standard'', July 21, 2005. Retrieved on January 5, 2008.</ref>
==History== Following the success of [[Nielsen SoundScan]] which tracked [[point of sale]] figures for music, the [[Nielsen Company]] decided to launch a similar service for book sales. Nielsen BookScan was launched in January 2001.<ref name=Slate/> Previously, tracking of book sales, such as by the [[New York Times Best Seller list]], was done without raw numbers. ''The New York Times'' would survey hundreds of outlets to estimate which books were selling the most copies, and would publish rankings but not figures. Only the publisher of a book tracked how many copies had been sold, but rarely shared this data.
==Methodology== Nielsen BookScan relies on point of sale data from a number of major book sellers. In 2009 Nielsen BookScan's US Consumer Market Panel covered 75% of retail sales.
==Use of BookScan== BookScan was initially greeted with skepticism, but is now widely used by both the publishing industry and the media.<ref name=PW/> Publishers use the numbers to track the success of their rivals. The media uses the figures as a reference to gauge a title's success. [[Daniel Gross]] of ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]'' has noted the increase of pundits using the figures to disparage each other.<ref name=Slate/>
BookScan also provided previously unavailable metrics on books published by multiple publishers, such as classic novels in the [[public domain]] which may be published by many different houses. Previously, no single entity had figures for the sales of these books; publishers and bookstores only knew their own sales. ''Slate'' noted that [[Jane Austen]]'s ''[[Pride and Prejudice]]'' was available from Amazon in 130 different editions; prior to BookScan there was no way to tabulate total sales. By summing BookScan data, however, ''Pride and Prejudice'' was reported to command sales of 110,000 a year, nearly 200 years after being published.<ref name=Slate2/>
BookScan records cash register sales of books by tracking ISBNs when a clerk scans the barcode. BookScan only tracks print book sales, thus excluding ebook sales from major e-tailers such as [[Amazon Kindle]], [[Barnes & Noble]] [[Nook]], [[Kobo eReader|Kobo]], [[Apple Inc.|Apple]], and [[Google Play]]. BookScan likewise does not include non-retail sales through channels such as libraries, nor specialty retailers who do not report to the service.<ref>https://electricliterature.com/everything-you-wanted-to-know-about-book-sales-but-were-afraid-to-ask-1fe6bc00aa2d#.jssavzqjs</ref>
BookScan and other services, as Pubtrack Digital, PubTrack Higher Education, PubTrack Christian, Books & Consumers, PubEasy und PubNet belong to [[The NPD Group]] since January, 2017.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.bookweb.org/news/nielsen-sells-bookscan-other-us-book-industry-services-npd-group-35494|title=Nielsen Sells BookScan, Other U.S. Book Industry Services to NPD Group|date=2017-01-20|work=American Booksellers Association|access-date=2018-07-04|language=en}}</ref> NPD has acquired these services from Nielsen’s '''U.S.''' market information and research services for the book industry. These services will be part of NPD Book, a new U.S. practice area.
Nielsen will offer these services furthermore in 9 countries outside U.S., named "Nielsen Book".<ref>[https://www.boersenblatt.net/artikel-marktdaten_in_den_usa.1279371.html Börsenblatt für den deutschen Buchhandel], january 20, 2017</ref>

{{Eastern Slavic name|Alexandrovich|Sorokin}} {{Infobox scientist |name = Pitirim Alexandrovich Sorokin |native_name = Питирим Александрович Сорокин |native_name_lang = Russian |image = Питирим Сорокин.jpg |image_size = 200px |caption = Sorokin in 1917 |birth_date = {{OldStyleDate|2 February|1889|21 January}} |birth_place = Turya, [[Vologda Governorate]], [[Russian Empire]] (now [[Komi Republic]], [[Russia]]) |death_date = {{death date and age|df=y|1968|02|10|1889|02|02}} |death_place = [[Winchester, Massachusetts]] |residence = |citizenship = * [[Russian Empire]] (1889–1917) * [[Statelessness|Stateless]] (1922–1930) * [[United States]] (1930–1968) |nationality = [[Russians|Russian]] |ethnicity = |field = [[sociology]] |workplaces = * Saint Petersburg Imperial University
* [[Harvard University]] * [[University of Minnesota]] |alma_mater = [[Saint Petersburg State University|Saint Petersburg Imperial University]] |doctoral_advisor = |doctoral_students = |known_for = |author_abbrev_bot = |author_abbrev_zoo = |influences = |influenced = |prizes = |religion = |footnotes = |spouse = Elena Petrovna Sorokina (née Baratynskaya) (1894–1975) }} '''Pitirim Alexandrovich Sorokin''' ({{IPAc-en|s|ə|ˈ|r|oʊ|k|ɪ|n|,_|s|ɔː|-}};[http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/sorokin "Sorokin"]. ''[[Random House Webster's Unabridged Dictionary]]''. {{lang-ru|Питири́м Алекса́ндрович Соро́кин}}, {{OldStyleDate|2 February|1889|21 January}} – 10 February 1968) was a [[Russian Empire|Russian]]-born American [[sociology|sociologist]] and [[political activist]], best known for his contributions to the [[social cycle theory]]. ==Background== Pitirim Alexandrovich Sorokin was born on {{OldStyleDate|2 February|1889|21 January}}, in Turya, a small village in [[Yarensk]] [[uyezd]], [[Vologda Governorate]], [[Russian Empire]] (now [[Knyazhpogostsky District]], [[Komi Republic]], [[Russia]]), the second son to a [[Russians|Russian]] father and [[Komi peoples|Komi]] mother. Sorokin's father, Alexander Prokopievich Sorokin, was from [[Veliky Ustyug]] and a travelling [[craft]]sman specializing in [[gold]] and [[silver]], while his mother, Pelageya Vasilievna, was a native of [[Zheshart]] and belonged to a [[peasant]] family. His elder brother, Vasily, was born in 1885, and his younger brother, Prokopy, was born in 1893. Sorokin's mother died on March 7, 1894, in the village of Kokvitsa, and after her death Sorokin and his elder brother Vasily stayed with their father, travelling with him through the villages in search of work, while Prokopy was taken in by his aunt, Anisya Vasilievna Rimsky, who lived with her husband, Vasily Ivanovich, in the village of Rimia. Sorokin's father began to develop [[alcoholism]], and following instances of physical abuse, he and Vasily left their father to be independent. In the early [[1900s (decade)|1900s]], supporting himself as an artisan and clerk, Sorokin attended the [[Saint Petersburg State University|Saint Petersburg Imperial University]] in [[Saint Petersburg]] where he earned his graduate degree in [[criminology]] and became a professor.Allen Phillip, J. (1963). Pitirim A. Sorokin in Review. Durham N.C. Duke University Press Sorokin was an [[anti-communist]], and during the [[Russian Revolution]] was a member of the [[Socialist Revolutionary Party]], supporter of the [[White Movement]], and a secretary to Prime Minister [[Alexander Kerensky]] who was a leader in the [[Russian Constituent Assembly]]. After the [[October Revolution]], Sorokin continued to fight [[communist]] leaders, and was arrested by the new regime several times before he was eventually [[Death sentence|condemned to death]]. After six weeks in prison, Sorokin was released and went back to teaching at the University of St. Petersburg, becoming the founder of the sociology department at the university. In 1922, Sorokin was again arrested and this time exiled by the [[Soviet]] government, emigrating in 1923 to the United States, and became a [[naturalized]] citizen in 1930. Sorokin was a leader among the Democrats leading up to the Russian revolution, and was sought by Lenin's forces after Lenin consolidated his power. After months in hiding, he escaped from the [[Soviet Union]] in 1922 and emigrated to the [[United States]], becoming a [[naturalized]] citizen in 1930.{{cite book|author=Sorokin, Pitirim|title=Дальняя дорога: автобиография|trans-title=Long journey: autobiography|date=1992|publisher=Terra|location=Moscow|page=9|language=Russian}} Sorokin was personally requested to accept a position at [[Harvard University]], founding the Department of Sociology and becoming a vocal critic of his colleague, [[Talcott Parsons]].Jeffries, Vincent. "Sorokin, Pitirim," Encyclopedia of Social Theory. California: Sage Publications.In "Fads and Foibles," Sorokin accuses Parsons of borrowing his work without acknowledgement. Sorokin was an ardent opponent of [[communism]], which he regarded as a "pest of man," and was a deputy of the [[Russian Constituent Assembly]]. Sorokin was professor of sociology at the [[University of Minnesota]] from 1924 to 1940, when he accepted an offer of a position by the president of [[Harvard University]], where he continued to work until 1959. One of his students was writer [[Myra Page]]. {{Cite book | first1 = Myra | last1 = Page | authorlink = Myra Page | first2 = Christina Looper | last2 = Baker | title = In a Generous Spirit: A First-Person Biography of Myra Page | publisher = University of Illinois Press | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=0DamHoxHiCkC | pages = 67 | date = 1996 | accessdate = 4 August 2018| isbn = 9780252065439 }} ==Works== Before his achievements as a professor in the United States, he published his 1924 ''Leaves of a Russian Diary'', by (E.P. Dutton & Co.), giving a daily, and sometimes hourly account of the Russian Revolution which actually first started in February 1917 where he was in the forefront of creating a provisionary government, only to see it unravel and lose power to the [[Bolsheviks]] in October 1917. In 1950, Sorokin published an addendum to the book called ''The Thirty Years After.'' It is a personal and brutally honest account of the revolution and of his exile. Sorokin's academic writings are extensive; he wrote 37 books and more than 400 articles. His controversial theories of social process and the historical typology of cultures are expounded in ''Social and Cultural Dynamics'' (4 vol., 1937–41; rev. and abridged ed. 1957) and many other works. Sorokin was also interested in social stratification, the history of sociological theory, and altruistic behavior. Sorokin's work addressed three major theories: social differentiation, social stratification and social conflict. The theory of social differentiation describes three types of societal relationships. The first is familistic, which is the type that we would generally strive for. It is the relationship that has the most solidarity, the values of everyone involved are considered, and there is a great deal of interaction. Social stratification refers to the fact that all societies are hierarchically divided, with upper and lower strata and unequal distribution of wealth, power, and influence across strata. There is always some mobility between these strata. People or groups may move up or down the hierarchy, acquiring or losing their power and influence. Social conflict refers to Sorokin's theory of war. Whether internal to a nation or international, peace is based on similarity of values among the people of a nation or between different nations. War has a destructive phase, when values are destroyed, and a declining phase, when some of values are restored. Sorokin thought that the number of wars would decrease with increased solidarity and decreased antagonism. If a society's values stressed altruism instead of egoism, the incidence of war would diminish. In his ''Social and Cultural Dynamics'', his magnum opus, Sorokin classified societies according to their 'cultural mentality', which can be "ideational" (reality is spiritual), "sensate" (reality is material), or "idealistic" (a synthesis of the two). He suggested that major civilizations evolve from an ideational to an idealistic, and eventually to a sensate mentality. Each of these phases of cultural development not only seeks to describe the nature of reality, but also stipulates the nature of human needs and goals to be satisfied, the extent to which they should be satisfied, and the methods of satisfaction. Sorokin has interpreted the contemporary Western civilization as a sensate civilization, dedicated to technological progress and prophesied its fall into [[decadence]] and the emergence of a new ideational or idealistic era. In ''Fads and Foibles'', he criticizes [[Lewis Terman]]'s ''Genetic Studies of Genius'' research, showing that his selected group of children with high [[IQ]]s did about as well as a random group of children selected from similar family backgrounds would have done.{{cite book|last=Gladwell|first=Malcolm|title=Outliers|year=2008|location=New York|isbn=978-0-316-03669-6|pages=90|url=http://www.goodreads.com/review/show/104760101}} ==Personal and death== Sorokin married Dr. [[Helen Baratynskaya]], with whom he had two sons. Sorokin died on 10 February 1968, in [[Winchester, Massachusetts]]. A [[Russian Orthodox]] service was held at home for the family, followed by an eclectic service at the [[Memorial Church of Harvard University]].Sergei P. Sorokin, "[http://cliffstreet.org/index.php/sergei-sorokin-about-pitirim Life With Pitirim Sorokin: A Younger Son's Perspective]". Sorokin's papers are currently held by the [[University of Saskatchewan]] in [[Saskatoon]], [[Canada]], where they are available to the public. In March 2009 the Sorokin Research Center was established at the facilities of [[Syktyvkar State University]] in [[Syktyvkar]], Republic of Komi, for the purpose of research and publication of archive materials, mainly from the collection at the University of Saskatchewan. The first research project "Selected Correspondence of Pitirim Sorokin: Scientist from Komi on The Service of Humanity" (in Russian) has been drafted and will be in print in the Fall of 2009 in Russia. {{cite web |url=http://www.pitirimsorokin.org |title=Sorokin Research Center (Russia, Komi Republic, Syktyvkar) |publisher=Sorokin Research Center |language=Russian |accessdate=2009-09-11}} ==Major works == ;In English or English translation *''Contemporary Sociological Theories '' NY: Harper, 1928 [https://web.archive.org/web/20170312195237/http://www.dli.ernet.in/handle/2015/49994 online free] *''Principles of Rural-Urban Sociology'' (with Carle C Zimmerman) New York : H. Holt, 1929, Preface: "a summary of Source book in rural sociology," in three volumes, prepared under the auspices of the U.S. Dept. of Agriculture and the University of Minnesota, to be published in 1930 or 1931" [http://www.worldcat.org/title/principles-of-rural-urban-sociology/oclc/4976487&referer=brief_results WorldCat item record] *''The Sociology of Revolution'' 1935 OCLC 84193425. <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Wasko,Mosco,Pendakur(1993)PhotographofD.W.jpg|thumb|[[Dallas Walker Smythe]], one of the first media scholars to conceptualize PEC.]] --> The '''political economy of communications''', news, or media, is a particular branch in [[Communication studies]] or [[media studies]] which studies the power relations ([[political economy]]) that constitute the communication of information from the [[mass media]] to its publics.<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title=New Media|last=Flew|first=Terry|last2=Smith|first2=Richard|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2014|isbn=978-0-19-900550-5|location=Don Mills, ON|pages=1–26, 57–75, 275}}</ref> The concept has been developed by media and political economy scholars, such as [[Dallas Walker Smythe]],<ref>{{cite conference|author=Melody, B.|year=1994|title=Dallas Smythe: Pioneer in the political economy of communications|editor=T. Guback|booktitle=Counterclockwise: Perspectives on communication|pages=1–6|location=Boulder, CO|publisher=Westview Press}}</ref> [[Herbert Schiller]], Vincent Mosco,<ref>{{Cite book|title=The political economy of communication rethinking and renewal|last=Vincent|first=Mosco|date=1998-01-01|publisher=Sage Publications|isbn=978-0803985605|oclc=490137496}}</ref> Dan Schiller, and [[Robert W. McChesney]].<ref>{{Cite book|title=The political economy of media : enduring issues, emerging dilemmas|last=1952-|first=McChesney, Robert Waterman|date=2008-01-01|publisher=Monthly Review Press|isbn=9781583671610|oclc=245202825}}</ref> More specifically, PEC analyzes the social relations between the mass media system, the communication technology, and the wider social/economic structure in which it operates (e.g., role of the state), with a focus on understanding both the historical emergence and current state of technological developments.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=Understanding Media Industries|last=Havens|first=Timothy|last2=Lotz|first2=Amanda D.|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2012|isbn=978-0-19-539767-3|location=New York, N. Y.|pages=2–9}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite book|title=The Political Economies of Media|last=Dal|first=Yong Jin|date=2011-01-01|publisher=Bloomsbury Academic|isbn=9781849664264|oclc=798294461}}</ref>
== Influences ==
One of the most early modern works in the political economy of communications are [[Harold Innis]]' works which were compiled in the book ''[[Empire and Communications]]''. This directly inspired [[Marshall McLuhan]], a colleague of Innis at the University of Toronto, who would later be made famous for the dictum "the medium is the message". Subsequent PEC approaches have been heavily influenced by Marxist thought and democratic politics, as it questions powers of and within communications against the realization of democracy.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hardy|first=Jonathan|date=2014-06-01|title=Critical political economy of communications: A mid-term review|url=http://www.ingentaconnect.com/content/intellect/mcp/2014/00000010/00000002/art00008|journal=International Journal of Media & Cultural Politics|volume=10|issue=2|pages=189–202|doi=10.1386/macp.10.2.189_1}}</ref> * [[Marxian economics|Marxist]] Thought- The [[Ethics|moral philosophy]] of PEC dictates it to often criticize [[capitalism]] for its effect on media and democracy, which originates from the [[Critical theory (Frankfurt School|critical theory]] works of [[Karl Marx]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Fuchs|first=Christan|date=2014|title=WikiLeaks and the Critique of the Political Economy|url=|journal=International Journal of Communication|volume=8|issue=1932–8036/2014FEA0002|pages=2718–2732}}</ref> A common critique of critical political economy (often from the [[cultural studies]] approach) is that, like [[Marxism|Marx]], it [[Fetishism|fetishizes]] [[capitalism]] and is deterministic [[Technological determinism|technologically]] and/or [[Economic determinism|economically]].<ref name=":1" /> * [[Democracy|Democratic Politics]]- PEC views media and information as the ultimate democratizer of power, and thus includes social [[Praxis (process)|praxis]] as a criterion. Ultimately, this means that PEC encourages [[media reform]] <nowiki/>and government intervention in the [[Market (economics)|marketplace.]]<ref name=":2" />
== Main Topics of Study ==
[[File:News Corp logo 2013.svg|thumb|Logo of [[News Corp]], a mass media conglomerate and a subject of concentrated ownership. ]] * [[Concentration of media ownership|Media ownership]]- Concentration of ownership in media industries as a result of [[Technological convergence|convergence]] and [[Conglomeration|media conglomeration]] under [[neoliberal economics]] have become a concern for media [[Diversity (business)|diversity]] and [[Democracy|democratic discourse]].<ref name=":0" /> * Support mechanisms- [[Advertising]], [[marketing]], [[Subscription business model|subscription]], [[social media]], and [[crowdfunding]] [[revenue]]s are examples of economic support for media organizations. Such mechanisms influence what types of [[Content (media)|content]] are published or not published, the nature of the [[commodity]] (content vs. [[the audience]] vs. [[advertisers]]) and are thus relevant to PEC studies.<ref name=":0" /> * [[Government policy]]- Policy [[Media regulation|regulates]] media and its economics in terms of ownership, affecting how [[Creative industries|media industries]] operate as well as the role of media in society.<ref name=":0" />
== Journalism/News Media ==
As [[Journalism|journalism/news media]] is the core to the functioning of democratic society.<ref>{{Cite book|jstor=10.5406/j.ctt1xcjws|title=Normative Theories of the Media: Journalism in Democratic Societies|last=Christians|first=Clifford G.|last2=Glasser|first2=Theodore L.|last3=McQuail|first3=Denis|last4=Nordenstreng|first4=Kaarle|last5=White|first5=Robert A.|date=2009-01-01|publisher=University of Illinois Press|isbn=9780252034237|doi=10.5406/j.ctt1xcjws|doi-broken-date=2018-11-04}}</ref> PEC works towards the goal of "healthy journalism."<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=McChesney|first=Robert W.|date=2012-10-01|title=Farewell to Journalism?|journal=Journalism Practice|volume=6|issue=5–6|pages=614–626|doi=10.1080/17512786.2012.683273|issn=1751-2786}}</ref> Unfortunately for democracy, the current state of news media around the world and especially that of [[Media of the United States|the United States]], falls short of the general consensus (among media scholars and democratic theory) on what is considered to be healthy [[journalism]]. This is due in part to the overwhelming amount of [[public relations]] material being posed as [[News media|news]].<ref name=":4"/><ref name=":3" />
It is in the interest of PEC that journalism instead provide a "rigorous account" of those in power, meet the information needs of all classes and people, be truthful, and act as an early warning system by providing a "wide range of informed opinions on the most important issues of our time."<ref name=":3" />
== New Media ==
[[Mass media|The mass media]] are undoubtedly experiencing considerable changes in platform, technology, and economic structure (e.g., [[crowdfunding]], [[social media]]) as the [[digital era]] continues to shift people toward "[[New media|new" media]].<ref name=":1" /> Traditional financial configurations and business models have been destabilized by this transformation. However, new mechanisms of power have emerged from this more open system of information and news creation. The availability of information can now be skewed or influenced through "search, aggregation, and digital distribution infrastructures" (p. 493).<ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=Picard|first=Robert G.|date=2014-09-03|title=Twilight or New Dawn of Journalism?|journal=Journalism Studies|volume=15|issue=5|pages=500–510|doi=10.1080/1461670X.2014.895530|issn=1461-670X}}</ref> Vincent Mosco's definition of political economic studies, where the "production, distribution, and consumption of resources, including communication resources” are essential, thus remains relevant even in times of [[new media]], since a new [[Network economy|(network) economy/society]] forms its ''own'' power relations.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The rise of the network society|last=Manuel.|first=Castells|date=2008-01-01|publisher=Blackwell|isbn=9780631221401|oclc=254487176}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=International encyclopedia of communication online|last=1949-|first=Donsbach, Wolfgang|last2=Association.|first2=International Communication|last3=(Firm)|first3=Wiley-Blackwell|date=2008-01-01|publisher=Wiley/Blackwell|isbn=9781405131995|oclc=271856987}}</ref><ref name=":4" /><ref>{{Cite book|chapter-url=http://users.ipfw.edu/tankel/Syllabi/Spring%202010/COM%20330/BBarrettPoliticaleconomy.pdf|title=Approaches to Media|last=Boyd-Barrett|first=Oliver|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=1995|isbn=|location=|pages=186–192|chapter=The political economy approach}}</ref>

[[File:NAMA Artémis Orthia.jpg|thumb|150px|Representation of the goddess [[Artemis Orthia]] in the usual stance of ''Potnia Theron'' on an archaic ivory [[ex-voto|votive offering]], ([[National Archaeological Museum of Athens]])]] [[File:Ankara Muzeum B19-36.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Seated Woman of Çatalhöyük|Seated goddess of Çatalhöyük]] flanked by two [[Felidae|felines]]]]
'''Potnia Theron''' (Ἡ Πότνια Θηρῶν, "The Mistress of the Animals") is a term first used (once) by [[Homer]] (Iliad 21. 470) and often used to describe female divinities associated with animals.<ref name=fatd>{{cite book|last=Fischer-Hansen|first=Tobias|title=From Artemis to Diana: the goddess of man and beast|year=2009|publisher=Museum Tusculanum Press|isbn=978-8763507882 |author2=Birte Poulsen|page=23}}</ref> The word ''[[Potnia]]'', meaning mistress or lady, was a [[Mycenaean Greek]] word inherited by [[Ancient Greek|Classical Greek]], with the same meaning, cognate to [[Sanskrit]] ''{{IAST|patnī}}.''<ref>{{cite book|last=Chadwick|first=John|title=The Mycenaean world|year=1976|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-29037-1|page=92}}</ref>
Homer's mention of ''potnia theron'' is thought to refer to [[Artemis]] and [[Walter Burkert]] describes this mention as "a well established formula".<ref>{{cite book|last=Burkert|first=Walter|title=Greek Religion|year=1987|publisher=Harvard University Press|isbn=978-0-674-36281-9|page=149}}</ref> An Artemis type deity, a 'Mistress of the Animals', is often assumed to have existed in prehistorical religion and often referred to as Potnia Theron, with some scholars positing a relationship between Artemis and goddesses depicted in Minoan art and "''Potnia Theron'' has become a generic term for any female associated with animals."<ref name=fatd /><ref>{{cite book|last=Roller|first=Lynn E.|title=In search of god the mother: the cult of Anatolian Cybele|year=1999|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=978-0-520-21024-0|page=139|quote=indefinite figures such as the Potnia Theron}}</ref>
Many depictions use a female version of the widespread ancient [[motif (visual arts)|motif]] of the male [[Master of Animals]], showing a central figure with a human form grasping two animals, one to each side. The oldest depiction has been discovered in [[Çatalhöyük]]. Another example of ''Potnia theròn'' is situated in Museo civico archeologico di Monte Rinaldo <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.retemusealedeisibillini.it/monterinaldo/|title=Monte Rinaldo - Rete Museale dei Sibillini|website=Retemusealedeisibillini.it|accessdate=11 April 2018}}</ref> in Italy: plate illustrates goddess that wears a [[Peplos|long dress]] and holds hands with two [[Panthera|panthers]].

'''Quelepa''' is an important archaeological site located in eastern [[El Salvador]]. Generally considered to have been settled by the [[Lenca people]], the site was founded around 400 BC, in the [[Mesoamerican chronology|Late Preclassic]] period (500 BC - AD 250).<ref>Sheets 2000, pp.420, 422.</ref> The inhabitants constructed a platform from plaster and [[pumice]] and rebuilt it a number of times. Artefacts recovered during the excavations of the site indicate that the local population depended upon [[subsistence agriculture]], these artefacts included ''[[metate]]s'' (a kind of [[mortar and pestle|mortar]]) and ''[[comal (cookware)|comales]]'' (a type of [[griddle]]). The site belonged to the [[Mesoamerica]]n cultural region.<ref>Sheets 2000, p.420.</ref> Quelepa means "stone jaguar" in the [[Lenca language]], probably in reference to the large Jaguar Altar found at the site.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, p.23.</ref>
Throughout its occupational history, the inhabitants crafted stone tools from [[Obsidian use in Mesoamerica|obsidian]].<ref>Sheets 2000, p.420.</ref> The site appears to have been linked to trade routes extending to western El Salvador and the [[Guatemalan Highlands]] and also to the north in [[Honduras]].<ref>Sheets 2000, pp.421-422.</ref>
Although sites in western El Salvador were severely affected by the eruption of the [[Lake Ilopango|Ilopango Volcano]] during the Early Classic, its only effect on Quelepa was the severance of trade routes into Mesoamerica. This cutting off did not result in stagnation at the site, but rather resulted in the florescence of a local culture.<ref>Cobos 1994, 1998, p.62. Sheets 2000, p.442.</ref>
==Location== [[File:Volcan de san miguel.jpg|thumb|right|The San Miguel volcano dominates the local topography]] The Quelepa archaeological site is located {{convert|1|km|mi}} outside the [[Quelepa, San Salvador|small village of the same name]].<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, p.23.</ref> The ruins are situated along the north bank of the San Esteban River, a tributary of the [[Río Grande de San Miguel]] which flows into the Pacific Ocean. The site is located {{convert|8|km|mi}} west-northwest of the town of [[San Miguel, El Salvador|San Miguel]].<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, pp.20, 23. Kelly 1996, p.310.</ref> Quelepa is {{convert|13|mi|km}} north of the neighbouring site of [[Los Llanitos]].<ref>Kelly 1996, p.310.</ref> The archaeological site divided into East and West groups by a small stream called the Quebrada Agua Zarca, which has high, steep banks.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, pp.23, 33.</ref> The ruins have an altitude of between {{convert|160|and|180|m|ft}} [[above mean sea level]].<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, p.28.</ref>
The archaeological remains of Quelepa are on privately owned land under cultivation, the entire East Group together with a part of the west group are on the land of the Hacienda El Obrajuelo farm.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, p.27.</ref> The area to the west of the Quebrada Agua Zarca is planted with [[maize]] and [[cotton]], as is the area south of the river.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, p.27.</ref>
The general area around Quelapa is part of the [[flood plain]] of the Río Grande de San Miguel, lying between the hills to the north and the [[San Miguel (volcano)|San Miguel volcano]] some {{convert|30|km|mi}} from the Pacific Ocean.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, p.28.</ref> The volcano is the most prominent local landmark, with its peak at {{convert|2132|m|ft}} above mean sea level. Although the volcano has erupted 6 times since 1699, most recently in 1924, and continues in a low state of activity it has never dropped sufficient [[volcanic ash]] on Quelepa to be detectable archaeologically.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, p.28.</ref>
The climate of Quelepa is classified under the [[Köppen climate classification|Köppen system]] as [[Tropical savanna climate|tropical wet and dry]]. The majority of rainfall falls between in months of September and October with a long [[dry season]] from November to May. Monthly rainfall averages between {{Convert|300|and|400|mm|in}} in September and less than {{convert|25|mm|in}} in March. Native [[fauna]] has been practically extinguished by the heavy use of [[pesticide]]s on the local cotton crops.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, pp.28-29.</ref> Andrews reported many [[iguana]]s near the watercourses and the occasional snake.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, p.29.</ref>
==History== Quelepa was founded around 400 BC, in the [[Mesoamerican chronology|Late Preclassic]] period (500 BC - AD 250).<ref>Sheets 2000, p.420.</ref> The first inhabitants of the site constructed a platform from plaster and [[pumice]] and rebuilt it a number of times<ref>Sheets 2000, p.420.</ref> Quelepa is generally considered to have been settled by the [[Lenca people]].<ref>Sheets 2000, p.422.</ref>
Around AD 200 the [[Ilopango (volcano)|Ilopango volcano]] erupted and devastated western El Salvador, breaking Quelepa's link with Mesoamerica. Between AD 150 and AD 625 Quelepa turned instead to the [[Intermediate Area]] beyond the frontiers of Mesoamerica, with artefacts arriving from the north and the east.<ref>Sheets 2000, p.442.</ref> The major ceremonial architecture of the East Group was built in the Early Classic.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, p.76.</ref>
In the [[Mesoamerican chronology|Late Classic]] to [[Mesoamerican chronology|Early Postclassic]] periods (from approximately AD 625–1000), the ceremonial centre of the settlement was abandoned and smaller structures were built around a small plaza. This has been interpreted as a Mesoamerican influence with its origins on the Gulf coast of Mexico, or perhaps from [[Seibal]], a [[Maya civilization|Maya]] city in the [[Petén Basin]] of northern [[Guatemala]].<ref>Sheets 2000, p.434.</ref> The stone facing from this period is cruder than that of earlier times and stairways replaced the earlier use of access ramps.<ref>Sheets 2000, p.434.</ref> The [[Mesoamerican ballcourt|ballcourt]] also dates to this time.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, p.76.</ref>
Quelepa as a whole was abandoned around AD 1000, at the beginning of the Early Postclassic period.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, p.59.</ref> The abandonment of the site has been linked to the arrival of the [[Pipil people]] in the El Salvador region, although there is no evidence that they ever occupied the site.<ref>Cobos 1994, 1998, p.81.</ref>
===Modern history=== The first mention of Quelepa in print was a brief description written by Atilio Peccorini and published in 1913. Herbert Spinden mentioned Quelepa in 1915 and Peccorini published another, even less detailed account in 1926. Peccorini reported that the site had many structures faced with stone, a paved "road", artificial terraces and various sculptured monuments, one of which was probably the Jaguar Altar.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, p.22.</ref> Also in 1926, Samuel K. Lothrop mentioned that he made a brief visit to the ruins to buy ceramics for the [[Museum of the American Indian]] in [[New York City]], he listed Quelepa in his list of archaeological sites in El Salvador under the alternative name of ''Mayacaquin''.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, p.22.</ref> The site was visited by Antonio Sol, the Director of the Departamento Nacional de Historia, in 1929.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, p.22.</ref>
The first excavation of the site took place in 1949, directed by Pedro Armillas. The investigations focused on Structure 3 in the East Group and were never completed and the results were unpublished, although the fieldnotes he made were forwarded to E. Wyllys Andrews V.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, p.22.</ref>
The principal excavations of the site were carried out under the direction of E. Wyllys Andrews from 1967–1969, funded by the [[Middle American Research Institute]] of [[Tulane University]] and by the [[United States Department of Health and Human Services|United States Department of Health, Education and Welfare]].<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, p.9.</ref>
Although the site is officially listed as a National Archaeological Monument, as recently as 2005 it was effectively unprotected.<ref>''El Diario de Hoy'' 29 April 2005.</ref>
==Site description== Quelepa has approximately 40 structures occupying an area of approximately {{convert|0.5|km2|sqmi}}.<ref>Kelly 1996, p.310.</ref> They are spread out over a distance of {{convert|1|km|mi}} along the bank of the San Esteban River, never at a distance greater the {{convert|500|m|ft}} from the river itself.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, p.23.</ref> Ceramic remains and isolated mounds extend as far as {{convert|3|km|mi}} from the site core.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, p.23.</ref> The site is divided into East and West Groups by a small stream.<ref>Kelly 1996, p.310.</ref> Structure size at the site varies greatly from {{convert|10|m|ft|adj=on}} high [[Mesoamerican pyramids|pyramids]] to small, badly eroded mounds. These smaller mounds probably served as platform bases for perishable structures.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, p.23.</ref> The site also possesses a [[Mesoamerican ballcourt]].<ref>Parsons 1991, p.202.</ref> Agricultural land use of the site continues to constantly erode the archaeological remains.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, p.27.</ref>
The site, unusually for Mesoamerica, features ramps in place of stairways for some structures. Ramps have also been reported from [[Los Naranjos, Honduras|Los Naranjos]] in [[Honduras]] and from [[Bilbao (Mesoamerican site)|Bilbao]] on the Pacific coast of [[Guatemala]], although the latter differed in form and function from those at Quelepa. In all cases, the ramps have been dated to the Classic period.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, p.72.</ref>
The two groups are fairly distinct in their architectural styles, probably due to being built in different periods. The West Group is probably the later of the two groups and is similar to a miniature [[Maya architecture|Maya-style acropolis]].<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, p.26.</ref>
The area south of the San Esteban River lacks structures but contains a great number of tombs.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, p.27.</ref>
A cache was uncovered at the site that contained a collection of artefacts associated with the [[Mesoamerican ballgame]], including finely sculpted yokes, ''palmas'' and a ''hacha''. They were all placed under a stone slab. These, together with other artefacts such as flutes and wheeled toys indicate a link with the Gulf coast of Mexico.<ref>Sheets 2000, p.434.</ref>
===West Group=== The structures of the West Group are located upon artificial terraces that are generally aligned north-south.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, p.23.</ref> To the south of the group the terrain descends steeply to the river.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, p.26.</ref> The group consists of a number of mounds, 15 of which are arranged around a rectangular plaza in the southeastern area of the group, most of them upon an artificial terrace.<ref>Kelly 1996, p.310. Andrews 1976, 1986, p.26.</ref> The northeast of this terrace supports a narrow platform upon which was built a long, low structure.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, p.26.</ref> A similar structure is on the east side of the plaza.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, p.26.</ref> The mounds in the West Group date to the Late Classic.<ref>Kelly 1996, p.310.</ref>
The I-shaped '''Ballcourt''' (denominated '''Structure 19''') is situated {{convert|110|m|ft}} north of the plaza, it has not been excavated. It consists of a mound measuring {{convert|31|m|ft}} long and {{convert|2.25|m|ft}} high that forms one side of the playing area, with the west side formed by the face of a terrace. The ballcourt is oriented north-south. The north and sound end zones are close by low, narrow walls running east-west. In the rain season, runoff water flows through the ballcourt and has buried it under more than {{convert|2|m|ft}} of soil. The original height of the sides of the ballcourt was probably around {{convert|4.5|m|ft}}. Two large stone slabs were laid in the centre of the playing area, upon them was a broken [[sandstone]] disc that measured {{convert|28|by|4.5|cm|in}} and was probably a ballcourt marker.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, pp.26, 76.</ref>
'''Structure 23''' is a small platform dating to the Late Classic. It is located near the edge of a high terrace and closes the west side of a small plaza. It is a single-level platform with vertical sides and measures {{convert|8.8|by|6.8|m|ft}} by {{convert|2.5|m|ft}} high. It was accessed by a {{convert|1.9|m|ft|adj=on}} wide stairway that extends {{convert|3|m|ft}} westwards from the platform. The use of a stairway indicates a major change in architectural style, moving away from the earlier use of ramps and involving the use of poorly reworked stone blocks for the facing of the building.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, pp.48-50.</ref> The platform and the stairway both contained a mix of earth, mud and rock infill. Burnt remains of [[wattle and daub]] were found scattered around the base, together with fragments of mortar and red-painted [[stucco]]. The wattle and daub suggests a perishable superstructure once stood upon the platform but it is not certain if the stucco came from this or from the platform itself.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, p.50.</ref> Offering 23 was excavated from the structure and contained three ceramic vessels, including a red effigy vessel. This offering was buried at the time the structure was built and was likely to have been a dedicatory offering.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, pp.50-51.</ref> A rough altar had been built in the angle formed by the southern wall of the stairway and the western wall of the platform itself.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, p.51.</ref>
'''Structure 28''' is a platform located {{convert|6|m|ft}} to the south of Structure 23. It measured {{convert|1.5|m|ft}} high and has been badly eroded. Its architectural style is identical to that of Structure 23, suggesting that it also dates from the Late Classic. The platform base was buried under a {{convert|25|cm|in|adj=on}} thick layer of burnt wattle and daub mixed with ceramic fragments, probably the remains of a perishable superstructure that once stood on top of the platform.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, p.52.</ref>
'''Structure 29''' is a small mound that was a three-tiered pyramid platform measuring {{convert|17.2|by|14.1|m|ft}} at the base. It is out of alignment with the other structures in the west group. The mound was {{convert|3.5|m|ft}} high when excavated but the structure's original height has been calculated as approximately {{convert|4.1|m|ft}} based on the angle of its stairway. The stone facing was poor quality, consisting of rough, unequal stones placed haphazardly and cemented with mud mortar. This was then roughly covered with a thick, uneven coating of mortar. The lowest tier of the platform was {{convert|0.7|m|ft}} high, the middle tier measured {{convert|1.8|m|ft}} in height and the third tier was approximately {{convert|1.6|m|ft}} high. The stairway climbed the west side of the platform and projected {{convert|1|m|ft}} from the base of the pyramid.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, pp.53-57.</ref> Structure 29 was built over an earlier structure that was similar in form.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, p.58.</ref> The poor workmanship associated with Structure 29 indicates that it was probably one of the last major structures to be erected at Quelepa. Ceramic evidence indicates that the building was abandoned at the end of the occupational history of the site, around AD 1000 at the beginning of the Early Postclassic period.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, p.59.</ref>
Offering 22 was found in front of Structure 29-sub and consisted of 3 ceramic discs piled on top of each other, a large [[obsidian use in Mesoamerica|obsidian]] knife, a piece of [[hematite|haematite]], a piece of dusty orange clay, and 43 flakes of obsidian.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, p.59.</ref> Offering 24 was found near the southeast corner of Structure 29 and was the most unusual offering found at Quelepa.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, p.58.</ref> A stone slab measuring {{convert|39|by|69|cm|in}} was placed on top of three U-shaped [[Mesoamerican ballgame#Clothing and gear|stone yokes]] laid out in an interlaced pattern, together two carved ''palmas'' and a sculpted ''hacha''.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, p.59.</ref> The larger ''palma'' measured {{convert|49|by|16.5|cm|in}} and was sculpted to represent a seated deity, probably [[Ehecatl]], the god of wind. The smaller ''palma'' measured {{convert|23.5|by|13.5|cm|in}} and represents a [[Feathered Serpent (deity)|feathered serpent]].<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, p.225.</ref> The ''palmas'' have been dated stylistically to the Late Classic and show affinities with ''palmas'' from [[Veracruz]] on the Gulf coast of [[Mexico]].<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, pp.225-228.</ref> All these items are associated with the Mesoamerican ballgame.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, p.228.</ref>
===East Group=== The East Group consists of structures clustered close to the edges of enormous artificial terraces. These terraces rise successively to the north as they get further from the river until the highest rests against the base of a range of hills.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, p.23.</ref> The massive terraces in the group provided a level base for the construction of further architecture. The terraces were faced with cut stone slabs laid horizontally.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, p.23.</ref>
Most of the structures in the group are aligned north-south, although a few are clustered in arranged groups.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, p.23.</ref> The two main structures at Quelepa are found in the East Group.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, p.23.</ref> They were step pyramids, distinguished from those normally built in Mesoamerica by having access ramps instead of stairways.<ref>Sheets 2000, p.420.</ref> Structure 3 is the larger of the two main buildings and Structure 4 is the smaller.<ref>Sheets 2000, p.420.</ref> Both buildings appear to have been abandoned in the mid-7th century AD.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, p.46.</ref> The two pyramids faced south towards the edge of their supporting terrace, one of the largest terraces at the site, and were accessed via Ramps 1 and 2 that climbed the terrace edge and were directly aligned with the access ramps of Structures 3 and 4 respectively. Both ramps were paved with massive slabs and rose at an angle of 13°.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, pp.46-47.</ref> The terrace and the ramps were faced with large volcanic [[tuff]] blocks similar to, but larger than, those used to build the base of Structure 3. The terrace facade measured approximately {{convert|4|m|ft}} high.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, pp.46-47.</ref>
'''Ramp 1''' extended {{convert|9.1|m|ft}} from the edge of the terrace, at the lower (southern) end it measured {{convert|12.1|m|ft}} wide, it narrowed as it rose and measured {{convert|10.9|m|ft}} wide where it met the terrace in front of the access ramp of Structure 3.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, p.47.</ref>
'''Ramp 2''' was {{convert|17.6|m|ft}} long and got wider as it rose. At the lower southern end it measured {{convert|8.1|m|ft}} wide, widening to {{convert|8.9|m|ft}} at the top. Ramp 2 is directly aligned with the access ramp of Structure 4.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, p.47.</ref> Three offerings were excavated from the base of Ramp 2. Offerings 20 and 21 were close to each other and each consisted of an inverted ceramic vessel placed over another vessel. Offering 18 was {{convert|3|m|ft}} northwest of the base of the ramp and contained two small ceramic bowls, one inverted over the other. All the ceramics from these offering belong to the Shila ceramic complex dated to the Early Classic.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, p.47.</ref>
====Structure 3==== Structure 3 is the largest structure at Quelepa. It is situated {{convert|11|m|ft}} to the east of the smaller pyramid Structure 4, on the third terrace rising northwards from the river. Both the terrace upon which it stands and the structure itself were faced with large, finely cut stone blocks. Structure 3 was built somewhat after Structure 4, which was already in use during its construction. Considerable effort was made to artificially level the volcanic [[tuff]] surface of the terrace before construction began. The pyramid probably had eight stepped levels, with the lowest measuring {{convert|48|by|32.3|m|ft}} and the highest measuring approximately {{convert|22.3|by|9.1|m|ft}}.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, pp.39-41.</ref> It is not aligned precisely with Structure 3, being oriented 5° east of north, a 10° variance from the earlier structure. The lower levels of the pyramid measured between {{convert|1.1|and|1.3|m|ft}} high, the fourth level was higher, measuring {{convert|1.7|m|ft}}. The lower levels had a horizontal depth of between {{convert|1.6|and|1.8|m|ft}}, the upper levels of approximately {{convert|2.5|m|ft}}.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, pp.39-41.</ref> The front (south) face of the pyramid was not straight, the angles of the southern corners were slightly greater than 90° with the facade of the pyramid extending out slightly to meet the access ramp.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, pp.39-41.</ref> The excavator concluded that this was to create the illusion that the building was larger than its actual size. The pyramidal base originally stood between {{convert|9.7|and|9.8|m|ft}} high.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, pp.39-41.</ref> The access ramp was {{convert|6.4|m|ft}} wide and originally faced in stone, as uncovered during the 1949 excavations by Pedro Armillas. However, after the excavations, the owners of the Hacienda La Obrajuelo stripped the stone facing to be reused as construction material in San Miguel. The surviving remains of the ramp project {{convert|8.8|m|ft}} from the front of the pyramid, ending {{convert|8|m|ft}} from the edge of the supporting terrace. The ramp had a total length of approximately {{convert|24|to|25|m|ft}} from base to summit and an initial incline of 18.5° that increased to 28° at the upper levels.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, pp.39-41.</ref> The south face of Structure 3, including the access ramp, is badly eroded with the damage having been accelerated by the original excavations at the site.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, pp.39-41.</ref> Structure 3 was built on top of an earlier structure that had been deliberately destroyed to make way for the new building. Structure 3-sub is estimated to have been {{convert|5|m|ft}} high. Construction of the final structure is estimated to have begun around AD 500.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, pp.45-46.</ref>
The tuff blocks used to dress the lower levels of the structure measure up to {{convert|150|by|70|cm|in}} by {{convert|30|cm|in}} and weigh over a ton, during excavations they were unable to be moved by ten men without mechanical aid. The upper levels of the pyramid used smaller blocks that were able to be carried by a single person. The walls of the pyramid were probably coated in plaster and the upper surfaces were paved.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, p.42.</ref> Pieces of burnt [[wattle and daub]] were found scattered all over the surface, sides and base of Structure 3, the remains of a perishable structure that once stood on top of the pyramid.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, p.44.</ref>
At least 3 offerings were buried under the floor of the summit of the pyramid. Offering 2 included a large stone disc placed upon a large cylindrical jade bead. Offering 3 included ceramics with a large grey-green river pebble placed on top. Offering 4 contained only an inverted polychrome bowl. A large offering was buried under the upper part of the ramp and was excavated by Pedro Armillas, the excavated artefacts passed into private ownership and their location are now unknown. The Offering included two large stone discs similar to that uncovered in Offering 2. Upon each disc was placed a four-legged ceramic vessel and underneath each disc were three stone balls measuring between {{convert|18|and|20|cm|in}} and placed in a triangle. Also underneath each stone disc was a large tubular jade bead. This offering also contained a ceramic vessel inverted upon another with [[charcoal]] between the two, and a large vessel inverted over a bowl that contained five [[jadeite]] beads and a [[nephrite]] ''hacha'', together with traces of a red pigment, probably [[cinnabar]]. A further bowl contained a small piece of charcoal.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, pp.42-43.</ref>
====Structure 4==== Structure 4 is the smaller of the two pyramids, it is also the earlier of the two buildings. It dates to the Early Classic period. The pyramid base is on the edge of the third terrace rising from the river and is near the centre of the East Group. The structure measures {{convert|34.5|by|18.8|m|ft}} and was aligned just under 5° west of north. The pyramid probably only had two levels, the upper level being set back a little rather than centred and measuring {{convert|27.2|by|15.3|m|ft}}. The lower level measured {{convert|2.6|m|ft}} high and the upper is estimated to have measured {{convert|3.2|m|ft}} high originally but was somewhat reduced. The total height of the pyramidal platform was about {{convert|5.8|m|ft}}. Access to the top of the pyramid was via a south-facing ramp that measured {{convert|11.9|m|ft}} long with the lower end extending {{convert|6.3|m|ft}} south of the pyramid base. The ramp was {{convert|5.4|m|ft}} wide and rose at an estimated angle of 27°. Excavations revealed that the ramp was built of compacted clay and that the pyramid was packed with unworked stones. Both were built simultaneously.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, pp.33-36, 79.</ref> Structure 4 was faced with rough volcanic tuff blocks that varied considerably in size, cemented with mud. The blocks were covered in a coating of mortar that varied between {{convert|5|and|7|cm|in}} thick and that may originally have been painted although no evidence was found to prove this.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, p.35.</ref> Around the base of the pyramid were found large amounts of burnt wattle and daub that can only have originated with the burning of a perishable superstructure on top of the pyramidal platform. The structure contained seven caches, among the offerings were Early Classic ceramic vessels, [[jade use in Mesoamerica|jade]] beads and an [[onyx]] bowl.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, p.37.</ref>
====Other structures and monuments==== At the western edge of the East Group is a large rectangular platform supporting architectural remains. The platform was once almost entirely enclosed by walls, leading to its description as a fortress, although the walls are now badly eroded.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, pp.23, 26.</ref> '''Structure 9''' is located at the southern edge of the platform.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, p.23.</ref>
The '''Jaguar Altar''' is a huge [[monolith]]ic monument that measures {{convert|314|by|297|cm|in}} by {{convert|85|cm|in}} high and dates to the Late Preclassic, it has a face sculpted on one side in the style of [[Cara Sucia (Mesoamerican site)|Cara Sucia]] and that has affinities with the sculptural styles of [[Kaminaljuyu]] in [[Guatemala]] and [[Izapa]] in southern [[Mexico]].<ref>Sheets 2000, p.421. Andrews 1976, 1986, p.233.</ref> The upper face of the altar has a {{convert|39|cm|in|adj=on}} deep square hollow that measures {{convert|140|by|160|cm|in}}.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, p.233.</ref> All four sides of the altar bear [[relief]] sculptures.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, p.234.</ref> The altar was removed from the site after Quelepa was excavated by E. Wyllys Andrews and is now in the [[Museo Nacional de Antropología Dr. David J. Guzmán]] in [[San Salvador]].<ref>Kelly 1996, p.311. Andrews 1976, 1986, p.47.</ref> It was found {{convert|235|m|ft}} north-northwest of Structure 29 and {{convert|102|m|ft}} northeast of the ballcourt. It had been placed near the edge of a {{convert|4|to|5|m|ft|adj=on}} high terrace.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, p.47.</ref> When excavated the area around and under it had already been explored by looters. It is not known if the altar was found in its original location or if it had been moved there, one corner of the altar had been broken off and archaeologists were unable to locate the missing fragment, suggesting that it had been broken while being moved.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, p.48.</ref>
'''Altar 2''' was found upon Structure 9 in this group.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, p.23.</ref> It measures {{convert|84|by|70|cm|in}} by {{convert|46|cm|in}} high and was removed to the Museo Nacional de Antropología. The altar is roughly circular with a square hollow carved out of the upper face.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, p.235.</ref>
'''Altar 3''' is a fragment that was found in 1970 a few metres east of Structure 36 in the West Group.<ref>Andrews 1976, 1986, p.235.</ref>

{{About|the month|}} {{Redirect2|Sep.|Sept.|other uses of Sep.|SEP (disambiguation){{!}}SEP|the family division|Sept}} {{pp-move|small=yes}} {{Month header}} {{Calendar}} [[File:Les Très Riches Heures du duc de Berry septembre.jpg|right|thumb|180px|September, from the ''[[Très Riches Heures du Duc de Berry]]'']] [[File:Liège (3).JPG|right|thumb|180px|[[School]] starts in September in many countries, such as here, in Belgium]] [[Image:September WPA poster.jpg|thumb|175px|right|[[Works Progress Administration|WPA]] poster, [[1940]]]] [[File:Logansapphire.jpg|thumb|right|175px|[[Sapphire]], September [[birthstone]]]] [[File:2008-05-04 at 18-26-44-Forgetmenot-Flower.jpg|thumb|right|175px|[[Forget-me-not]], September birth flower]] '''September''' is the ninth month of the year in the [[Julian calendar|Julian]] and [[Gregorian calendar]]s, the third of four months to have a length of 30 days, and the fourth of five months to have a length of less than 31 days. In the [[Northern Hemisphere]] September is the seasonal equivalent of [[March]] in the [[Southern Hemisphere]].
In the Northern hemisphere, the beginning of the meteorological [[autumn]] is on 1 September. In the Southern hemisphere, the beginning of the meteorological [[Spring (season)|spring]] is on 1 September.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20090225040732/http://www.metoffice.gov.uk/climatechange/guide/effects/seasons.html|title=Met Office: Changing seasons|first=Met|last=Office|website=webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk}}</ref>
September marks the beginning of the [[Eastern Orthodox liturgical calendar|ecclesiastical year]] in the [[Eastern Orthodox Church]]. It is the start of the [[academic term|academic year]] in many countries, in which children go back to school after the [[Summer vacation|summer break]], sometimes on [[September 1|the first day of the month]].
[[September (Roman month)|September]] (from Latin ''septem'', "seven") was originally the seventh of ten months on the oldest known [[Roman calendar]], with March (Latin ''[[Martius (month)|Martius]]'') the first month of the year until perhaps as late as 153 BC.<ref>[[H.H. Scullard]], ''Festivals and Ceremonies of the Roman Republic'' (Cornell University Press, 1981), p. 84; Gary Forsythe, ''Time in Roman Religion: One Thousand Years of Religious History'' (Routledge, 2012), p. 14.</ref> After the calendar reform that added [[Ianuarius|January]] and [[Februarius|February]] to the beginning of the year, September became the ninth month, but retained its name. It had 29 days until the Julian reform, which added a day.
[[Ancient Roman]] observances for September include [[Ludi Romani]], originally celebrated from September 12 to September 14, later extended to September 5 to September 19. In the 1st century BC, an extra day was added in honor of the deified Julius Caesar on 4 September. [[Epulum Jovis]] was held on September 13. [[Ludi Triumphales]] was held from September 18–22. The [[Septimontium]] was celebrated in September, and on December 11 on later calendars. These dates do not correspond to the modern Gregorian calendar. In 1752, the [[British Empire]] adopted the [[Gregorian calendar]]. In the British Empire that year, [[September 2]] was immediately followed by [[September 14]].
September was called "harvest month" in [[Charlemagne]]'s calendar.<ref name="eb1911">{{Cite EB1911|wstitle=September}}</ref> September corresponds partly to the [[Fructidor]] and partly to the [[Vendémiaire]] of the [[First French Republic|first French republic]].<ref name="eb1911"/> On [[Usenet]], it is said that September 1993 ([[Eternal September]]) never ended. September is called ''Herbstmonat'', harvest month, in Switzerland.<ref name="eb1911"/> The [[Anglo-Saxon]]s called the month ''Gerstmonath'', barley month, that crop being then usually harvested.<ref name="eb1911"/>
==September in Astronomy and Astrology== [[Meteor showers]] that occur in September include the [[Aurigids]], the [[Delta Aurigids]] which occur from mid-September to early October, the [[Taurids#Appearance|Southern Taurids]], which occur from September 10 to November 20, and the [[Andromedids]] which occur from September 25 – December 25.
The [[September equinox]] takes place in this month, and certain observances are organized around it. It is the [[Autumn]] equinox in the Northern Hemisphere, and the [[Vernal Equinox]] in the Southern Hemisphere. The dates can vary from 21 September to 24 September (in [[UTC]]).
September is mostly in the sixth month of the astrological calendar (and the first part of the seventh), which begins at the end of March/Mars/Aries.
==September symbols== * September's [[birthstone]] is the [[sapphire]]. * The birth flowers for September are the [[forget-me-not]], [[morning glory]] and [[aster (genus)|aster]].<ref>{{cite web |author= SHG Resources |url= http://www.shgresources.com/gems/birthflowers |title= SHGresources.com |publisher=SHGresources.com |accessdate= 2013-08-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.flowerstower.com/singleflower.php?name=Forget-me-not |title=Flowerstower.com |accessdate=2013-08-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130224103640/http://www.flowerstower.com/singleflower.php?name=Forget-me-not |archivedate=February 24, 2013 }}</ref> * The [[zodiac]] signs for the month of September are [[Virgo (astrology)|Virgo]] and [[Libra (astrology)|Libra]] whose end and start are related to equinox date (usually 22 or 23 September).
